editionStmt.edition: This early release includes some 500 EEBO-TCP transcriptions of Early Modern plays that have undergone several routines to create an interoperable and algorithmically amenable corpus of Early Modern Drama. Many incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words have been corrected, including obvious printers' errors, but the text has not been proofread word by word. Each word in the text has been identified as a distinct token with its own xml:id and assigned to a lemma, a part of speech, and a standard spelling. Speech prefixes were mapped to unique speaker ID's as "who" attributes of sp elements. elements

respStmt.resp: Incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words were reviewed and in many cases fixed by
respStmt.name: Melina Yeh

respStmt.resp: Tokenization and linguistic annotation using MorphAdorner and NUPOS 2.0 were provided by
respStmt.name: Philip R. Burns

respStmt.resp: With the help of Thomas L. Berger's Index of Characters in Early Modern English Drama Printed Plays, 1500-1660 speech prefixes were mapped to unique "who" attributes of sp elements by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: A provisional, rudimentry, and algorithmically produced castlist was added as a new div in the back listing each role with their number of speeches sorted from high to low by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

div.p: The history of the trial of chivalry, with the life and death of cavaliero Dick Bowyer.
As it hath been lately acted by the right honourable the Earl of Derby his servants.
London printed by Simon Stafford for Nathaniel butter, and are to be sold at his shop in Paul's churchyard, near s. Austin's gate. 1605.

div.head: The history of the trial of chivalry.
div.stage: Enter Lewes, King of France, Philip his son, Katharina, his daughter, Rodorick, and Flaunders with drum and colours, and soldiers at one door: at the other, enter Navar, Ferdinand, Bellamira, and the Earl of Pembroke, and Burbon.
div.l: Duke Rodorick, and my noble cousin Flanders:
Are your battalions ready for the charge?

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Ten thousand men of Orleans I command,
And those are bravely marshalled on the plain,
Ready to be commanded by your highness.

sp.speaker: Flaund.
sp.l: As many of the warlike brood of Mars
Do call me general: those, my gracious lord,
Together with myself I recommend,
To be commanded by your majesty.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Thanks, Earl of Flanders, Duke of Orleans, thanks,
What lets us that we charge not on the foe?

sp.speaker: Navar.
sp.l: My lord of Pembroke, are your Englishmen
Squadroned with ours, and ready for the charge?

sp.speaker: Pem.
sp.l: The French and English make one warlike body,
Whereof your highness is the moving head:
Or peace or war, as pleaseth you direct.

sp.speaker: Nau.
sp.l: Then war, and give the signal through the host.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Navarre, Navarre, submission were more meet,
Then to add blood to wrong.

sp.speaker: Nau.
sp.l: What wrong, King Lewes?
The kingdom of Navarre we will acknowledge
To hold of none but of the King of Kings.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Three hundred years prescriptions on our sides,
So long thy ancestors by fealty
Have held thy kingdom of the crown of France.

sp.speaker: Pem.
sp.l: Talk not of years, years limit not a crown,
There's no prescription to enthral a King:
he finds it written in the rolls of time,
Navar's a kingdom solely absolute,
And by collusion of the Kings of France,
Because it lies so fitly upon France,
The people speaking all one mother tongue,
It hath been wrested for a royalty,
Untruly due unto the crown of France.
That Pembroke speaks the truth, behold my sword,
Which shall approve my words substantial.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Pembroke, you are too plain in your discourse.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: I tell thee, Roderick, Pembroke soldier-like
Hath truly opened, what ten thousand lives
Will hardly do, if war be made the judge.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: If war be judge? why, shallow-witted Burbon,
Who shall decide this difference, but war?
Hath not the judge put on his scarlet robe?
Is not the field prepared? our men in armour?
The trumpets ready for the sound of death?
And nothing hinders us but our own words?
Leave idle parley, my dread sovereign lord,
And soon resolve the Duke in fire and smoke,
That he maintains a title false and forged,
And that Navarre is a usurping lord.

sp.speaker: Na.
sp.l: On that I'll hazard all these valiant lives.
Sound drums and trumpets, make King Lewes know,
He makes his best friend prove his greatest foe.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Why pause our drums? our trumpets, speak as loud,
Till the bright air be made a purple cloud.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Pause, gracious father.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Noble father, pause.
Let Ferdinand thy son so far prevail,
That peace, not war may end this difference.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: For Bellamira's sake abstain from war.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Philip thy son humbly desires a peace.
Let not my father sheathe his warlike sword
Within the bowels of his countrymen.

sp.speaker: Kath.
sp.l: Thy daughter Katharina prays the like.

sp.speaker: Nau.
sp.l: From whence proceeds this sudden sound of peace?
Comes it from me? what, from my Ferdinand?
From Bellamira my sweet second self?

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Or rather comes it (Lewes) from thy soul?
Thy Philip, the true image of thyself?
Thy Katharina, thy hearts chiefest joy?

sp.speaker: Rod:
sp.l: Princes, you ask, you know not what yourselves.

sp.speaker: Pem.
sp.l: Rodorick, they ask a sweet and pleasing boon.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Why, they ask peace, and we are set for war.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: 'Tis a bad peace exceeds not a just war.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: We will not rise from this submissive ground,
Till we obtain, if not a peace, a truce.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Nor shall our feet be guilty of new steps,
Till I obtain a truce from murdering war.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Show me some reason (Son) for this demand.

sp.speaker: Nau.
sp.l: Show me some reason (Children) for this prayer.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: I love the daughter of thine enemy.
Fair Katharina hath enthralled my heart.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I love the daughter of thine enemy,
Fair Bellamira hath enthralled my heart.

sp.speaker: Pem.
sp.l: Is love the cause? then wherefore wage we war?
What matter is't who wears both diadems,
When the succession lives in either's heir?
If Ferdinand be crowned King of Navarre,
Fair Katharina shall be crowned his Queen:
If Philip wear the diadem of France,
Fair Bellamira made his lovely Queen,
Sways half the sceptre. See what heaven can do,
Provide for peace, even in the jaws of war!

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.l: How sweetly doth the Earl of Pembroke speak!
Now trust me I am ravished with his voice.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: What says Navarre? what, is't war or peace?

sp.speaker: Na.
sp.l: A truce for three months, so it please your highness,
During which time our children shall have leave,
With drum and trumpet to survey the camp,
to court our daughters, and to feast themselves,
As fits the sons of honourable foes:
And if it prove a match between them both,
There end all difference, I'll bequeath my crown,
As a rich offering to their nuptial rites.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Here, strike the truce upon my kingly hand,
Which is as surely ratified in this,
As by the testimonial of a world.
So now, for three months space all wars surcease,
Our thoughts are wholly fixed on love and peace.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Zounds, here's a truce made up by miracle.

sp.speaker: Burb.
sp.l: I'll cross it by a wily stratagem.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: What stratagem?

sp.speaker: Burb.
sp.l: By love to Bellamira.
O could I dive into the prince's heart,
By any insinuation never so base,
How easily might I effect my plot,
To make the kingdom of Navarre mine own.
'Twere but a dram or so unto the son,
And a small thing would send the old man hence.
What, noble Rodorick, to gain a crown,
A Duke would do much.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: More than poison two:
But you, my lord, forget yourself too far,
Know you to whom you have disclosed your heart?

sp.speaker: Burb.
sp.l: Why, to the Duke of Orleans.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: The dear friend of Lewes the French King.

sp.speaker: Burb.
sp.l: King me no Kings,
Although we seem to be of several sides,
Rodorick, we love together like true friends.
This truce gives aim to our intention:
Assist me (Worthy Orleans) to effect,
First, my desired love, and next the crown.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Peter de lions is your lordship's servant,
A boon companion, and a lusty knave:
he is in love with Bellamira's maid,
And by that love he may bestead your highness,
More than your best friends in your best designs.
Call him forth.

sp.speaker: Burb.
sp.l: What Peter.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Here, my lord.

sp.speaker: Burb.
sp.l: Why dost thou look so wildly?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Not with drink, nor yet with rage.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: His looks are wild with love.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: With love surreverence? can there be a face
In all the world patched up with eyes and lips,
A forehead, and a pair of crimson cheeks,
To make me do at on, to make me look wild?

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Come, come, 'tis known that you love Thomasin.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Zounds, they that know that, know my heart and all,
I have not the power to deny it, 'tis most true.

sp.speaker: Burb.
sp.l: And 'tis most true that I love Bellamira:
Now if thou art in favour of thy wench,
Many a meeting thou mayst help me to,
And learn besides what suitors seek her love,
And whom she most affects. These things once known,
'Twere worth a dukedom, Peter.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: 'Sblood, give me a dukedom, and I'll warrant you
The knowledge of these things ten times o'er.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: There's angels for thee, Peter, think on them,
And do thy best to help thy master's love.
Well, howsoever I smooth it to the Duke,
My thoughts are bent on his destruction.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: You have my heart in your purse, I'll do any thing for you.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: And thou shalt want no gold, and so farewell.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p:
I cannot choose but farewell, and have the good angels to comfort me; yet I am melancholy. Here's gold to make me merry: oh but (Heigh ho) here's love to make me sad. To avoid prolixity, I am crossed with a suitor, that wants a piece of his tongue, and that makes him come lisping home: they call him cavaliero Bowyer, he will have no nay, but the wench. By these hilts, such another swashbuckler lives not
in the nine quarters of the world: why, he came over with the Earl of Pembroke; and he limps, and he limps, and he devours more French ground at two paces, than will serve Thomasin at nineteen. If ever he speak French, to avoid prolixity, he will murder the tongue. I'll provide for him, there's but small choice, either he shall renounce the wench, or forsake his lame legs, his lisping tongue, and his life to: for by s. Denis, I had rather die in a ditch, then be bobbed of my fair Thomasin.

div.stage: Enter at one door Philip and Rodorick, a drummer before them, with his drum at his back: at the other door, Ferdinand and Pembroke with their drummer ▪

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Whither goes royal Philip thus prepared?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: On what adventure goes prince Ferdinand?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: To conquer all the world, fair Katharine,
Whose beauty in mine eye surmounts it far.
Virtue and love conducts me to your sister.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: On the like voyage are my fortunes bound,
I go to win thy sister.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Some fair star,
On our great hopes shine fair and debonair.

sp.speaker: Pem.
sp.l: Amen, say Pembroke.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Amen, say Roderick.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: This way my love dwells.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: In this air breathes mine.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: Farewell.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Prince Ferdinand, if these cross loves
Enjoy a wished success, peace here shall dwell.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: And we be friendly brothers.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: True.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: Farewell.

sp.speaker: Pem.
sp.l: Pity such true love, which like blessed seed,
Sown in such fertile soil, his princely breast,
By the rough stormy brow and winter's hate
of adverse parents should be timeless nipped,
And die ere it attain maturity:
For I have heard, the Princess whom he serves,
Is hotly courted by the Duke of Burbon,
Who to effect his choice, hath in these wars
Furnished your father with a gallant power:
His love may haply then disable Philip's.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: O no, my father doth affect the prince:
Besides, my sister's heart is so combined
To his in perfect love, that Bourbon's hate,
Nor all the world that knot can separate.
Then sorrow not for him, but turn the stream
Of gentle pity on thy wretched friend,
Within whose bosom love hath kindled fire,
So ardent, that the flames will bury me.
Philip is throned in my sister's eyes:
But in my love disdain and hatred lies.

sp.speaker: Pem.
sp.l: Doth she not pay true kindness with the like?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: As stepdames, orphans, night, the clear-faced day,
So doth she hate me, and return my woes,
Like a steeled anvil backward on myself.
She is all hate, yet such a lovely foe,
That I must kiss the sword that wounds me so.

sp.speaker: Pem.
sp.l: Inter these thoughts, this is her father's tent.
Drum, give a friendly summons to the King.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Forbear a while (Dear Pembroke:) by our vows,
Which in the book of heaven are registered,
By all the rights of friendship, by that love
Thou bearest thy native country, I conjure thee,
This day to be the trumpet of my worth,
To speak the passions of thy grieved friend,
To Katherine's ears, till those pure ivory gates,
Pierced with the volley of thy battering words,
Give way to my laments to touch her heart:
For this have I extracted thee from many,
Made thee my fellow pilgrim to her shrine,
knowing thy thoughts from love's religion free ▪
When my prayers fail, thy tongue may plead for me.

sp.speaker: Pem.
sp.l: Must I be spokesman? Pembroke plead for love?
Whose tongue tuned to the instruments of war,
Never knew strain of fancy on my breath:
Affection never dwelled, but war and death.
But if thou lov'dst to have thy soldiers fight,
Or hearten the spent courages of men,
Pembroke could use a style invincible.
Lov'dst thou a town, I de teach thee how to woo her ▪
With words of thunder-bullets wrapped in fire,
Till with thy cannon battery she relent,
And humble her proud heart to stoop to thee.
Or if not this, then mount thee on a steed,
Whose courage never awed an iron bit,
And thou shalt hear me hollow to the beast,
And with commanding accents master him:
This courtship Pembroke knows; but idle love,
The slick-faced object of an amorous brain,
Did never clothe mine eyeballs, never taught
This tongue enured to broils and stratagems,
The passionate language of a troubled heart:
I am too blunt and rude for such nice service.
Yet since my friend enjoins me to this task,
Take courage, I'll both speak, plead, woo for thee,
And when I want fit words to move her mind,
I'll draw my sword, and swear she must be kind.
Drummer report our presence to the King.

div.stage: A parley, and answered. Enter France, Flaunders, and attendants.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Prince Ferdinand, and honoured English Pembroke,
Now by s. Denis, welcome. One run straight,
And give our daughter notice of these guests.
What man, we know you come prepared to woo:
to woo, to win; now by our sacred life,
We wish in soul our daughter were your wife.
Our son is with your sister, fair hap wait:
For peace or war lives in your love or hate.
Welcome once more, first, we'll go see your love,
After, to banquet, and from thence to woo.
Be merry, then we'll share a friendly part,
But you shall triumph in our daughter's heart.

div.stage: Enter Katharina, her man Bowyer, and a painter.

sp.speaker: Kath.
sp.l: See that the tent be ready furnished.
By this, my father and those lords are met,
Amongst whom, the noble Pembroke, like the sun,
Outshines the borrowed glory of the rest:
And well I may compare him to the sun,
That but once looked upon with his fair shape,
Hath dazzled my poor senses, and left me blind.
But sirrah, where's the man I bade you bring?

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.l: If you can judge of colours (Madam) this is he.
Paynter, stand forth.

sp.speaker: Kath.
sp.l: An earnest cause (My friend) importunes me,
Wherein I am to crave thy cunningest art.

sp.speaker: Payn.
sp.l: Such as it is, you may command, fair Princess.

sp.speaker: Kath.
sp.l: But are thy colours fresh? thy pencil smooth?
Thy hand unwavering? and thy head dislodged
Of all unquiet harsh encumbrances?
For thou must draw proportion of those parts,
Whose worth to tell, my tongue wants utterance.

sp.speaker: Payn.
sp.l: Fear you not (Madam) I am well prepared.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.l: Then hither straight with youthful Ferdinand,
Navarre's stout son, there comes an English knight,
Pembroke they call him, honourably born:
Him (Whilst we are in conference) thou shalt mark,
And to the life set down his counterfeit.
Nor is it needful I should show him thee,
The goodliest person in the train, that's he.

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.p: Let me alone to give the painter destruction, I know him as well as the beggar knows his dish: he wears a white scarf in his hat, and an orange tawny feather upon his arm.

sp.speaker: Kath.
sp.l: Fool, indirectly thou describest another:
That's prince Navarre, Pembroke his plume is azure,
A little intermixed with spotless white,
Prefiguring the temper of the sky,
With whose high motion his great mind doth move.

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.p: Orange tawny and azure, all's one, all is but feather, there is no difference I am sure but in colour.

sp.speaker: Kath.
sp.l: Why, that's as much as may be, is it not?

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.p: Not so, I'll prove the contrary: you are fair, and I am foul, is that all the difference between you and I? there's another thing in it, if you mark it well.

sp.speaker: Kath.
sp.l: I prithee peace, and with thy ignorance
Draw not the painter likewise into error.
Here take thy stand, thou knowest him by these marks
I lately spoke of: seem to excel thine art,
And I will study to requite thy pains.

div.stage: Enter Lewes, Ferdinand, Pembroke, Rodoricke, and Flaunders.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Thus did the Greeks, when they begird the walls
Of strong built Troy, sometimes with friendly check
Entertain peace, and spend their frolic hours,
In courtly feasting of each other foe.
Welcome (Young Ferdinand) I promise you,
It cheers my spirit we do embrace you here,
And welcome too (Brave lord) we cannot say,
As if we were in Paris; we might say,
Your viands shall be costly: but presume,
Such as the camp affords, we'll have the best.
Daughter, I prithee bid them welcome.

sp.speaker: Kath.
sp.l: My lord, I do
That with the congee of a bent knee:
But this with my true heart's loyalty.
Lords, you are welcome, by my father's leave.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Why, now thou dost content thy father, Kate,
When wholly unto merriment inclined,
Thou answer'st with like sympathy of mind.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: But yet her looks are haggard and obscure,
Which makes me doubtful she'll not stoop to lure.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Princes, let's enter: come, I'll lead the way:
The feast is mine, you are my guests this day.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Now Pembroke, show thy friendships true effect,
Obtain her love, my life thou shalt protect.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.l: He stays behind the rest, oh happy hour!
Work on (Sweet painter) to enrich mine eye
With that, which else procures my tragedy.

sp.speaker: Pem.
sp.l: Fair madam, in this confluence of sweet joy,
When every one resorts unto the feast,
Methinks you should not thus retire alone,
As seeming, your best fare were heavy moan.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.l: I am not (Sir) alone, nor do I starve
My appetite with any wilful fast,
I have a banquet of sweet pleasing thoughts;
That is more precious than the costliest feast.

sp.speaker: Pem.
sp.l: But at your father's board there sits a guest,
To whom the cup of Ganymede will seem
But juice of hemlock, and the daintiest dish,
As much unsavoury as the pumice stone,
Unless your presence season his delight.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.l: I am sorry I want skill to serve his diet.
I have not been instructed to such end.

sp.speaker: Pem.
sp.l: But I will teach you (Madam) if you please.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.l: Rather the party grieved first should show
Wherein we err, else how can we discern
What is our fault, or how we may amend?

sp.speaker: Pem.
sp.l: That office he commits unto my tongue.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.l: Is he not able then to speak himself?

sp.speaker: Pem.
sp.l: Yes, madam, I have heard when Ferdinand,
With whom in Padua I was conversant,
So spoke in the assembly of the learned,
With such a grace and well composed phrase,
As many thought grave Tully's eloquence
Flowed like a honey river from his lips.

sp.speaker: Kath.
sp.l: He wanteth then belike sufficient courage.

sp.speaker: Pem.
sp.l: Never lived knight less prejudiced in that,
Then valiant Ferdinand, whom I have seen,
Couch his staff lance with such dexterity,
As if the god of battle had himself
Entered the lists, and pressing to the midst
Of steel-composed troops, like lightning fly,
Till he had made a passage with his sword.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.l: So puissant in his fortitude with men,
And daunted with a silly woman's looks?
How can that be?

sp.speaker: Pem.
sp.l: Yes, when you weigh the force
Of your resistless and controlling beauty,
It is your beauty: were his power and spirit
Ten times more haughty venturous then it is,
Compels it stoop in homage to your foot,
As trembling lambs, when they to lions couch.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.l: 'Twas well he chose so good an orator,
To plead the imperfection of his cause.

sp.speaker: Pem.
sp.l: I should have that opinion of myself,
If for my sake your grace would favour him.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.l: Yes, for your sake we have endured his name;
And for your sake we tolerate his suit:
But when you cease to speak, than all that praise
You have attributed to his desert,
Seems borrowed from yourself, you are the man
Whose eloquence compares with Cicero's.
You are the man, whose knightly fortitude
Lives in the world unprejudiced of any.
You vanquish beauty, and enthral the mind
Of female weakness, with no lesser awe,
Then Indian vassals stoop unto their lords.
The name of Ferdinand you have mista'ne:
Say 'tis yourself, and then your whole discourse
Observes the perfect method that it should.

sp.speaker: Pem.
sp.l: Should I be false and treacherous to my friend?
I am entreated but to speak for him.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.l: But for yourself would be more acceptable.
O pardon me, nor let immodest strain
Cleave to my brow, my love is chastely bred,
Other than Pembroke, Katharine never vows,
Shall be enthronized in her maiden thoughts.

sp.speaker: Pem.
sp.l: Mistake me not, I say 'tis Ferdinand
Dies in affection to your deity.

sp.speaker: Kath.
sp.l: But in affection I survive to none,
But only Pembroke.

sp.speaker: Pem.
sp.l: Will you be esteemed
A cruel murderess of a loyal friend?

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.l: Will Pembroke triumph in a woman's fall?

sp.speaker: Pem.
sp.l: You anger me, respect young Ferdinand.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.l: You please me not, to speak of Ferdinand.

sp.speaker: Pem.
sp.l: Nay, then 'tis time to go, or wrong my friend.
Since, madam, what I would I cannot do,
Mine honour here bids me leave off to woo.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.l: Stay, Pembroke, Katharine will sue to thee,
So shalt thou keep thy faith and loyalty.

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.p: Tarry, sir, tarry, we want the length of your nose: nay, if you will not hear, I'll be so bold as follow your nose. Sir, tarry, tarry.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.l: He will not hear, nor (Too unkind) look back.

sp.speaker: Payn.
sp.l: But, madam, spite his heart you shall see this.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.l: Give me his picture: image far more kind,
Then is the substance, whence thou art derived!
Which way soever I divert myself,
Thou seemst to follow with a loving eye.
Thee will I therefore hold within mine arms,
As some small comfort to increasing harms.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: What means my second self by this long stay?
I cannot rest till I be certified,
What good or bad success my suit returns:
But he is gone, and in fair Katherine's hand
I see his picture. What may this pretend?

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.l: Thou hast done well indeed, in every part
Thou showst complete and cunning workmanship:
His eye, his lip, his cheek are rightly framed;
But one thing thou hast grossly overslipped.
Where is his stubborn unrelenting heart,
That lurks in secret as his master doth,
Disdaining to regard or pity me?

sp.speaker: Payn.
sp.l: Madam, his heart must be imagined
By the description of the outward parts.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.l: O no; for then it would be tractable,
Mild and applausive as the others be.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: No prince, but Pembroke dwells in Katherine's eye,
Who's that disturbs our pleasing solitude.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Know you not me? my name is Ferdinand,
Whose faithful love lord Pembroke late commenced?

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.l: Speak then for Pembroke as he did for you,
Or else your bootless suit will soon be cold.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Why, he was orator in my behalf:
If I should speak for him, as he for me,
Then should I breathe forth his passions, not mine own.
Ay, ay, 'tis so, the villain, in my name,
Hath purchased her affection for himself,
And therefore was he absent from the feast:
And therefore shuns my sight, and leaves behind
This counterfeit, to keep him still in mind.
'Tis so, 'tis so, base traitor, for this wrong
My sword shall cut out thy perfidious tongue.

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.p:
I have run till I sweat, sweat till my shirt cleaves to my back, cried till I am hoarse, and am hoarse till I
cannot cry, and yet he will not come back.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.l: No matter, fellow, I have here a pledge,
Which I will zealously devote me to.
There's thy reward, withdraw, my father comes.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Where are these lords? the one hath sat with me,
And suddenly is risen from the board:
The other came not at all. Daughter, saw you
The prince or Pembroke, which way they are gone?

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.l: Back to their tents, my lord, as I suppose.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Back to their tents, and take no leave of us?
Nay, than I fear their meaning was too smooth,
And some black treason covered in their smiles,
Which we will seek immediately to prevent.

div.stage: Enter Dick Bowyer, and soldiers, with drum and colours.

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.l: Stand, give the word along, stand.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.l: Stand there.

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.l: Lieutenant.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.l: Captain.

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.l: Is the watch set in the King's quarter yet?

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.l: An hour ago.

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.p: Zounds, what foolish Canaanits were they, to run in debt to their eyes for an hour's sleep, sooner than they needed? Sergeant.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Anon sir.

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.p: Anon sir! s'hart, the rogue answers like a drawer: but 'tis the trick of most of these sergeants, all clincum, clancum. God's dynes, I am an onion, if I had not rather serve foremost in the forlorn hoop of a battle, or run point blank against the mouth of a double charged cannon, then come under the arrests of some of their pewter pessels: zounds, 'tis hotter a great deal than hell mouth, et dives burning in sulphur: but thou art none of the genealogy of them. Where must we watch tonight ?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: In the furthest trenches that confront the enemy's camp.

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.p: That's the next way to have all our throats cut.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: That cannot be, you know, captain, there's a peace towards.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: A pox a peace, it keeps our ancient whole; but s'hart our gaberdines go to wrack: but foutra: 'tis well known, since Dick Bowyer came to France, he hath showed himself a gentleman and a cavaliero, and sets fear at's heels: and I could scape (A pox on it) th'other thing, I might haps return safe and sound to England; but what remedy? all flesh is grass, and some of us must needs be scorched in this hot country. Lieutenant Core, prithee lead my band to their quarter, and the rogues do not as they should, cram thyself, good core, down their throats, and choke them. Who stand sentronel tonight , sir?

sp.speaker: Soldier
sp.p: That must I, captain.

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.p: You, Rafe nod? zounds, soldiers, follow my discipline, say your prayers, you are all dead men, all dust and ashes, all worm's meat.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: How so, captain?

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.p: Do you make him sentronel? s'hart, he'll nod presently: and he do not sleep sitting upon the point of a Spanish needle, Dick bowyer's a very shuttlecock. Nod! zounds, he is one of the nine sleepers, a very dormouse: and I had a pageant to present, of the seven deadly sins, he should play sloth: and he did not sleep when he should speak his part, I am a badger.

sp.speaker: Soldier
sp.p: That's true, you have half the nature of a badger, for one leg is shorter than another.

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.p:
Zounds, you rogue, do not you know that? I'll tell you: s'hart, and I lie, call me Jebusite. Once as I was fighting in s. George's fields, and blind Cupid seeing me, and taking me for some valiant Achilles , he took his shaft, and shot me right into the left heel, and ever since, Dick Bowyer hath been lame: but my heart is as sound as a bell, heart of oak, spirit, spirit. Lieutenant, discharge nod,
and let cricket stand sentronel, till I come.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: He shall, captain.

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.p: On afore, strike drum, march soldiers, keep your place, nod: lusty my hearts, for the honour of England, and our brave general, the Earl of Pembroke. So, I have discharged myself of these.

Hot shot! now to my love: some may say, the tale of Venus loving Mars, is a fable: but he that is a true soldier, and a gent. as Dick Bowyer is, and he do not love some varlet or other, zounds, he is worse than a gaping oyster without liquor. There's a pretty sweet faced mother that waits on the Princess, that I have some mind to; but a whoreson Achitophel, a parasite, a rogue, one whose face looks worse than a tailor's cushion, of old shreds and colours; zounds, like a weaver's leg, in an old ditch feeding horseleeches, and this trotter is my rival, and loves Thomasin: his name is Peter de lions; but s'hart (I will not swear neither) if I do not turn Rich. Cour de lion with him, if I do not tear out his heart and eat it with mustard,Enter Peter, and Thomasinlet him say Dick bowyer's a mackerell. Yonder he comes with my property hand in hand. Zounds, I say nothing: but I'll hear what they say, and determine afterwards.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Thomasin, you know me, I hate prolixity: in a word, my humour is thus, I love you.

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.p: And I do not spoil that humour, so —

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Your answer compendiously, and avoid prolixity.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Marry muff! by Jesu, I scorn to humble the least part about me, to give answer to such a trotting question: as I live, it jolts mine ears worse in hearing, than the prince's coach on a broken causeway.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Thomasin, leave this pace, and take me with you: my lord loves your lady, yet I hear say, she is this night betrothed to the prince of France: so I love you, and shall I lose you? No, I hate prolixity: in a word, the end is, I'll marry you.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Pretty, as God save me! what will captain Bowyer say to that, if he should know it?

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.p: A good rogue, by Jesu.

sp.speaker: Pe.
sp.p: Bowyer a captain? A capon, a button mould, a lame haberdine, a red beard sprat, a yellow hammer, a bow case, a very jackdaw with his tongue slit.

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.p: Zounds, what a philistine is this? what a dictionary of proper names hath the rogue got together? heart, his tongue crawls as fast as the cheese doth in Germany. I'll pierce you for this, you lobster.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Bowyer, mordu foutra for him; and that sour crab do but leer at thee, I shall squeeze him to vargis.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: And you squeeze me, I may haps grow saucy with you, you whoreson burnd pudding pie, you dry parsnip: kiss me, Thomasin: so, dare you stand to your word now, and squeeze me?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Stumps, I challenge thee for this indignity. Bowyer, I will gird myself with thy guts, I am a soldier and a captain.

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.p: Captain? s'hart, and thou hast under thy charge, any other than pigmies, I am Gogmagog. Dost thou hear (Sowgelder?) and I do not with six cranes (Well marshalled) overrun thee and thy hundred and fifty, say Dick bowyer's a coward.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: For that word, draw.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Hold, gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.p: Peace (Good Thomasin) silence, sweet socket. Peter, dost see this sword? this sword killed Sarlaboys, that was one rogue: now it shall kill thee, that's two rogues. Whoreson puttock, no garbage serve you but this? have at you.

sp.speaker: Pem.
sp.l: Who's this at enmity within our camps?
What, Bowyer, and the servant to great Burbon?
Both sheathe your weapons: by our martial law,
This act is death.

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.p:
I'll be hanged then. Dost thou hear, noble general? Dick Bowyer knows what belongs to service: we did not draw of any malice, by this element of iron and steel, but to measure which of our swords were longest. I'll save
you for once, you Sarazen, because I see you'll hang scurvily: but the next time —

sp.speaker: Pem.
sp.l: Good captain Bowyer, let our English troops
Keep a strong watch tonight : my throbbing heart,
Like to a screech-owl in the midnight hour,
Bodes some black scene of mischief imminent.

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.p: Never fear (General) if Julius Caesar rise up against us, ere he do my lord any wrong, zounds, I'll be cut smaller than potherbs. I'll to the trenches, come Thomasin. Leer not, lobster, lest I thum that russeting face of yours with my sword hilt, till that it look as pied coloured as the rainbow. By Jesu I'll do it, and therefore follow me not.

sp.speaker: Pem.
sp.l: Why should this load of grief lie on my heart
With such a ponderous weight? I know no cause,
Unless it be by thinking on the wrong
My friend receives in the unmatched love,
Which Katharine bears me: yet my faith is sound,
And like a solid rock shall check her tears.
Katharine loves me; yet for my friend's delight,
Pembroke will hate her love, and fly her sight.

div.stage: Enter Burbon, Navar, Philip, Bellamira, Rodoricke, and attendants.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: Navarre, you sprinkle me with foul reproach,
And dim the lustre of our royal name,
With colours of dishonour.

sp.speaker: Nau.
sp.l: Hear me, Burbon.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: What words can satisfy so great a wrong?
Have you not with consent of all your lords,
Promised your daughter to this generous prince?

sp.speaker: Nau.
sp.l: Their true love forced us to it.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: True love? 'tis feigned.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Ha, Burbon.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Gentle Philip.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: With my sword,
I'll prove my love unfeigned, thee a false lord.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: This like a sanctuary frees thy tongue,
And gives thee childish liberty of speech,
Which else would fawn and crouch at Bourbon's frown.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Now by s. Denis —

sp.speaker: Burb.
sp.l: I'll not chat with boys.
Navarre, to thee I speak: thy daughters looks,
Like the North star to the sea-tossed mariners,
Hath brought me through all dangers, made me turn
Our royal palace, to this stage of death,
Our state and pleasures, to a bloody camp,
And with the strength and puissance of our force,
To lift thy falling and decayed state,
Even to her pristine glory, in thy quarrel
Burbon hath set himself against his King,
And soiled his greatness with a traitor's name.
Now when our worth expected rich reward,
Fair Bellamira, wonder of her time,
Must Philip have her?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Burbon, she is mine.

sp.speaker: Bur. Mordew:
sp.l: I'll be revenged, by heaven I will,
Or I will pave these plains with the dead bodies
Of our dear subjects: we have sworn thy fall,
That oaths thy death, our rage thy funeral.

sp.speaker: Nau.
sp.l: Hear our excuse.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: We will not credit air.
Peter, watch Rodorick, when the prince is gone,
Tell him, I'd speak with him.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Enough, 'tis done.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: Navarre, this setting sun, which sees our wrong,
Shall e'er his morrow's beams guide the proud East,
View Hymen's rites turned to a tragic feast

sp.speaker: Na.
sp.l: His anger bears him hence, young prince of France,
Since to reduce our enmity to love,
And thereby like a fair and lovely bride,
To marry peace to France, we are content,
To bring the sea-tossed bark of your affects,
half shipwrecked with the tempest of these wars,
To their desired port, as we agreed:
Go to your father, and inform him thus:
If personally he'll view our friendly tents,
And seal these articles of peace proposed,
This night you shall be troth-plight to our child.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Were it to search the furthest Northern clime,
Where frosty Hiems with an icy mace,
Strikes dead all living things, I'd find it out,
And borrowing fire from those fair sunny eyne,
Thaw winter's frost, and warm that dead cold clime:
But this impose is nothing, honoured King,
I'll to my father, and conduct him hither:
For whilst my soul is parted from her sight,
This earth is hell, this day a tedious night.
Come Rodorick, you shall bear me company.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: He shall not, for I'll stay him instantly.

sp.speaker: Nau.
sp.l: 'Twere pity to keep two such loves asunder.
Daughter, you and your ladies to your tent,
And deck you richly to receive the prince.
My lord of Pembroke, happily returned:
How doth our son? See where he comes himself.
Speak, boy, how spedst thou with fair Katharine?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: I know not how: is trothless Pembroke there?

sp.speaker: Nau.
sp.l: Be not dismayed, at length she'll pity thee.
Son, bid our officers adorn our court
In her chief glory: for this happy night
Shall set a period to this smarting war.
Your sister shall be troth-plight to prince Philip,
And France and we made friends about it then.
Pembroke, have you the charge to see our captains
Prepare a martial welcome to the King.
I'll not be idle: since Navarre was crowned,
Our heart with so much joy did never abound.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Nor mine with so much hate. Pembroke, a word.

sp.speaker: Pem.
sp.l: What wills your grace?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: That Pembroke is a villain.
Look not so strange, I speak it not your friend,
But he that in his soul hath sworn thine end.

sp.speaker: Pem.
sp.l: A villain? and my death? I am amazed.
Art thou awake? or is all this a dream?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: A dream of death: meet me tomorrow morning,
As thou art Pembroke and a gentleman,
By yond fair riverside , which parts our camps.
You know the place, come armed, and so farewell.

sp.speaker: Pem.
sp.l: Dear friend.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Push, meet me.

sp.speaker: Pem.
sp.l: Ferdinand, I will.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Revenge, smile on, thou shalt drink blood thy fill.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: This is my waiting night, 'tis for no good,
That I stand sentronel. Well, good or ill,
I care not greatly, so I get the gold:
Therefore to avoid prolixity, here walk I.
Here comes the men that must reward my pain.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: Have you the poison?

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: And a strong one too.
Here's a preservative to save your hand.
When Roderick fails your lordship, heaven shall fail,
To illuminate the world with cheerful light.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: Then here about should Peter wait for me:
For this is the pavilion of the Princess.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: My lord.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: Peter.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Here is the key that opens to the tent,
I stole it from my sweet heart Thomasin.
Enter without prolixity, woo and win the lady:
But give me gold (My lord) and I'll to dice.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: Hold, take thy fill.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: And it shall go as fast.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: Now gentle Peter, get thee unto rest:
my business craves the absence of the world ▪
None but my self and Roderick shall behold
The secret complot that I do intend.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: I go, my lord.

sp.speaker: Burb.
sp.l: Now blessed key, open unto my love,
Do more than loving lines or words can do:
My letters have been answered with disdain:
Her father I have moved to gain my love,
But he is frosty in my fervent suit,
And now perforce I will obtain my love,
Or ease her puling hatred by revenge.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: You stay too long, I'll help to turn the key.

div.stage: Discover her sitting in a chair asleep.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: What do I see? the majesty of heaven,
Sit in a maiden slumber on the earth?
What, is my Bellamira turned a goddess,
Within the table of her glorious face!
Methinks , the pure extraction of all beauty
Flows in abundance to my lovesick eye.
O, Roderick, she is admirably fair:
And sleeping, if her beauty be so rare,
How will her eyes inchant me if she wake!
Here, take the poison, I'll not stain that face,
For all the treasure of the western island.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: I see no such admired perfection.
Waken her, Burbon, and this loving charm,
Which now hath led your sense's prisoner,
Will vanish, and her speech full of reproof,
Beget a new phantasma all of hate:
Thou wilt detest her when she shall deny thee.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: Waken her, Rodorick, for I want the power.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: I hope I am disguised sufficiently,
That Bellamira cannot know my face.
Madam, fair Bellamira.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Here I am, who calls on Bellamira?

sp.speaker: Burb.
sp.l: Ay, fair love,
The Duke of Burbon that doth honour thee.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: The Duke of Burbon in my tent so late?
Where is my guard? what Peter, Thomasin.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Step to her, and restrain her, lest she call:
I'll be a looker on, and be unknown.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: What needs your highness call for any guard,
Since you are guarded with a faithful friend?
Behold me, madam, humbly on my knee,
Come to renew my suit, vouchsafe me love,
Or with this weapon take away my life:
Much better 'twere a thousand times to die,
Then live in torment of your scorching eye.
You have inflamed my heart, o quench that flame,
Or into cinders turn my hapless trunk:
Hapless, in being unbeloved of you.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: My lord of Burbon, you presume too much
On th'extremity of passion.
Have I not answered many an idle letter,
With full assurance that I cannot love?
Have I not often, viva voce checked
Your courtly kindness? frowned upon your smiles?
Used you unkindly, all to wean your love?
And do you still persever in your suit?
I tell thee, Burbon, this bold part of thine,
To break into my tent at dead of night,
Deserves severe correction, and the more,
Because it brings mine honour into question.
I charge thee, as thou art a gentleman,
Betake thee to thine own pavilion,
And let this answer satisfy for all:
Burbon, I cannot, nor I will not love thee.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: Cannot, nor will not? zounds, madam, but you must.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Must I?

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: And shall.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: You will not force me to it?

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: Or force that sparkling beauty from your face.
Look not so fiercely, nor cry out for help:
For if you do, this makes you cry your last.
Sing neither words, kind letters, hearty sighs,
Humble entreaty, nor a world of pain,
Can move you to take pity of my love:
But tyrantlike, your beauty seeks my life,
I will blot out that beauty with this juice.
Thus, thus I wipe away my passions:
Thus do I heal the torments of my love ▪
Thus do I ransom my enthralled eye,
And by depriving of the cause of life,
Kill th' effect, which was a world of sorrow.
Farewell, foul Bellamira, I am pleased
In this revenge, that no way could be eased.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Zounds, he has don't: now, Rodorick, joy thy fill.
Burbon is thine, the dukedom is thine own:
For only he in the inheritance
Stood as an obstacle, to let my claim.
This deed of his will take away his life:
And then let me alone to enjoy his land.
I'll steal away unseen, cause unsuspected:
I would not for the world be once detected.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Poison my face! o most inhumane wretch!
Revenge more vile, than to abridge my life.
What, Thomasin, what, brother Ferdinand:
My kingly father: is there none that hears?
Then treason, treason, let that waken you:
For capital is this offence to me.

div.stage: Enter Navar, Pembroke, Ferdinand, and Thomasin.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: O Jesu, mistress, what ails your face!

sp.speaker: Nau.
sp.l: Her face!

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: 'Tis spotted like a panther's skin.

sp.speaker: Pemb.
sp.l: O, were those spots as kindly beautiful,
Then were fair Bellamira undeformed.

sp.speaker: Nau.
sp.l: O, what divine power hath sent this leprosy?

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Say, beauteous sister.

sp.speaker: Pemb.
sp.l: Speak, fair Bellamira.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Speak, my good mistress.

sp.speaker: Nau.
sp.l: My sweet daughter, speak.

sp.speaker: Pem.
sp.l: Her silence argues a tormented spirit.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Thy countenance argues a deceitful soul.

div.stage: Enter Lewes, Philip, Rodoricke, and Flaunders.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Where is Navarre?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Where is fair Bellamira?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: My Philip, o give leave to fly his sight.

sp.speaker: Nau.
sp.l: Stay, gentle daughter, he'll not injure thee.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Here are the articles concluded on,
I could not rest, till I had signed them,
And brought them to your highness. A month hence
The marriage shall be fully solemnised,
So please your majesty and your fair daughter:
Are you content?

sp.speaker: Nau.
sp.l: To live in discontent.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Methinks , this royal presence hath dim looks:
Is it because they are in the arms of night,
Which sets a leaden lustre on the eye?
Or hath some accident accosted them,
That troubles their aspect with melancholy?
Is Navarre well? is Ferdinando well?
Is Pembroke well? Is Bellamira well?
O, where is Bellamira? tell me, princes,
For now my tongue hath struck upon her name.
I feel a kind of killing ecstasy.
Where is she? in her tent?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Deny me, father,
I would not see prince Philip with this face.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Why speak you not? what, have I touched the string,
Whereon the burden of your sorrow lies?
Father, look round about, see you my love?
Roderick, look round about, see you my love?

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: I see her not.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Nor I.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I say not so.
The garments that she wears, mine eye should know.
What lady's this that hides her heavenly face?
Here are no basilisks with killing eyes:
You need not hide your beauty: sweet, look up,
Methinks I have an interest in these looks.
What's here, a leper amongst noble men?
What creatures this? why stays she in this place?
O, 'tis no marvel though she hide her face:
For 'tis infectious: let her leave the presence,
Or leprosy will cleave unto us all.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: O let me leave the presence, gentle father,
When Philip bids his Bellamira go.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: My Bellamira!

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: How? my sons beloved!

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Is this my love? was this your beauteous child?

sp.speaker: Nau.
sp.l: My child.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: My sister.

sp.speaker: Pemb.
sp.l: Beauteous Bellamira.

sp.speaker: Nau.
sp.l: Spotted.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Disfigured.

sp.speaker: Pemb.
sp.l: Made a loathsome leper.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: How came this sudden alteration?
For she was comely, lovely, beautiful,
When the day left his chariot to the night.

sp.speaker: Na.
sp.l: That heaven doth know, and only Bellamira.
Daughter, I charge thee, tell me how it came.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Burbon, o Burbon.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Did he do the deed?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: He came into my tent at dead of night,
And rubbed my face with an infectious herb,
Because I would not grant unto his love.
I cried for help, but none did succour me.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: I know he did, and laugh to think on't.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: And he shall rue his treason.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Threaten not,
Leave the revenge to me whom it concerns,
'Tis I am robbed of a delicious look,
A heavenly sparkling brow, a starry eye,
a countenance fairer than Aurora's looks,
When all the East is guilded with her blush.
'Tis I will be revenged: but not before
I have espoused my lovely Bellamira.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Espoused her!

sp.speaker: Nau.
sp.l: How! marry a face deformed!

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: A leprous creature!

sp.speaker: Pem.
sp.l: An infectious maid!

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: One, whose sores are perchance incurable!

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Be they incurable, it is my love,
And for my sake she hath endured this wrong ▪
And, should I now forsake her thus distressed,
I could not merit a true lover's name.
To show I love her, I will marry her,
Before the month expire: nay in the morn:
Delays, perchance, may make her think I scorn.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Marry with me? fetch me a looking glass,
That I may see how sweet a bride I am.
O, I detest myself: dear, hate me too:
I am not to be married but to death.
Though I were empress of the spacious world,
I de lay myself and kingdom at thy feet.
Live, noble Philip, joy some happier match:
'Tis my unworthiness makes me deny thee.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Thinkst thou, because thy face is spotted so,
Thou art not worthy of thy Philip's love?
Thy face to me was but a marshal,
To lodge thy sacred person in my mind,
Which long ago is surely chambered there:
And now what needs an outward harbinger?
I do affect, not superficially:
My love extendeth further than the skin.
The inward Bellamira 'tis I seek,
And unto her will Philip be espoused.

sp.speaker: Nau.
sp.l: O admirable love!

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: O, my dear son,
Thou makest me famous by thy loyalty.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: I never heard the like.

sp.speaker: Pemb.
sp.l: Pen never writ.
A worthier story to posterity.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Pen never writ of a more treacherous friend,
Then, Pembroke, thou hast proved to Ferdinand.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Sweet love, prepare thee to be Philip's bride:
For here I swear, as I am royal born,
I'll marry thee, before the morning's sun
Hath run the third part of his glorious course.
Father, good night: dear friends, dear love, good night:
Marriage, I hope, will make my spirits more light.

sp.speaker: Nau.
sp.l: Good night, sweet son. King Lewes, stay with me,
Be thou my comforter, I'll comfort thee.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Pembroke, remember that thou fail me not.

sp.speaker: Pem.
sp.l: O God, what may these moody looks intend?
Methinks , I should have better from my friend.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Now, Bellamira, thou hast time to think
Upon these troublous matters: should I suffer
So brave a gentleman as Philip is,
To wed himself to my unworthy self,
It would be counted virtue in the prince;
But I were worthy of a world of blame.
No, Philip, no, thou shalt not wrong thine honour,
Nor be impeached by Bellamira's spots.
In some disguise I'll steal away tonight ,
And never appear more in my Philip's sight.

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.p:
There is no toil to this walking of the round: s'hart, I have been stumbling up and down all this night, like a brewer's horse, that has never a good eye in his head: 'tis as dark as pitch. I can resemble our camp to nothing better than hell, save that in hell they are always waking, and here the villains are as drowsy as swine. Lieutenant nod! why, you might have shot a double cannon in his ear, and never have waked him:
I jogged, and I jogged; I shouted, and I shouted; and yet the mongrel snorted, you might hear him to Dover: at last, I dragged him by the heels into a ditch of water, and there left the lobster crawling. A the tother side, Core being appointed to stand sentinel upon the Wallounes quarter, s'hart, the loach gets me into a sutler's bath, and there sits me drinking for Joan's best cap: but by this hand, and as Dick Bowyer is a soldier, and a cavaliero, he shall sit in the bolts for it tomorrow. My comfort is in these extremities, that I brought Thomasin to her lady's tent, leaving her new-come lover to pick straws: but soft, qui vou la?

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: My name is Ferdinand.

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.p: Stand.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: Why, captain, thou dost know me well enough.

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.p: Know, or not know, without the word you pass not.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: Soliman.

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.p: So, ally, ally, monsieur.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: First, tell me, sawest thou Pembroke come this way?

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.p: I saw him not.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: Farewell.

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.p: As much to you. Zounds, these Frenchmen think to outface us with a card of ten: but, and his beard were made of brass, Dick Bowyer will make him know the discipline of war. Here comes another.

sp.speaker: Pem.
sp.p: Who's there? Dick Bowyer?

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.p: Some call me so, what then?

sp.speaker: Pem.
sp.p: Pembroke salutes thee.

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.p: O, good morrow, my lord, good morrow.

sp.speaker: Pem.
sp.p: I prithee, captain, sawest thou Ferdinand, son to Navarre, as thou didst walk the round?

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.p: Even now, my lord, he passed along this way.

sp.speaker: Pem.
sp.p: Himself alone? or had he company?

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.p: Nay questionless, he was alone, my lord.

sp.speaker: Pem.
sp.p: Couldst thou discern his face? how did he look?

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.p: Faith, scurvily, my lord, like a green cheese, or the inside of a rotten pompion.

sp.speaker: Pem.
sp.p: There is crowns for thee to drink.

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.p: I thank your lordship. To see the difference between these French curs, and our English cavaliers: there's as much bounty in them, as there's marchpane in a dish of almond butter. I might have stood here till my teeth chatter in my head, ere the tother lancepresado would have said, here, captain Bowyer, there's a cardecue, to wash down melancholy. But had I known as much, I would have basted him, till his bones had rattled in his skin.

div.stage: Enter core and other soldiers, bringing in the clown.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Come, sir, you shall answer your walking before our captain.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Well, sirs, take heed what you do, I am a prince's man, if you stay me upon the Kings high way, I can lay fellowship to your charge.

sp.speaker: Core.
sp.p: But sirrah, we can lay treason to thine, for being without the word.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Without the word! O pernicious Frenchman! without the word! why, I have called thee villain, him rascal; this, slave; that, rogue; and am I still without the word?

sp.speaker: Core.
sp.p: Ay, sir, the word that must serve your turn, the watchword.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Faith, you're like to watch this twelvemonth, ere you have any other words at my hands.

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.p: How now masters, what calf are you dragging to the slaughterhouse there? ha?

sp.speaker: Core.
sp.p: A straggler, and a spy: captain, I pray examine him.

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.p: So, lieutenant Core, you are crept from your cups at last, I'll talk with you anon: but, sirrah, to you: from whence come you?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: I came, sir, from the King of France's camp.

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.p: So, what's your name?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: My name, sir, is bow wow.

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.p: S'hart, what a name's that! the hedgehog mocks us: bow wow, quotha? what kin art thou to the generation of dogs?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: No dog, sir, would you should know it, though I be encompassed with curs.

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.p: Zounds, he calls us curs, hang the hotchpotch up in a fathom or two of match.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Not you, sir, I call not you so: I know you to be a very insufficient ill-spoken gentleman.

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.p: Well, sirrah, whom do you serve?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: My master, sir, is the lady Katharine, the French King's daughter: I have been abroad about some business of hers, and am now going back again.

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.p: An honourable lady, sir: let him go: 'tis against the law of arms to stay him.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Stand of: but soft, I do not know your name, sir, that my lady may give you thanks.

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.p: My name's Dick Bowyer.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Then, master Dick Bowyer, after my hearty commendations, adieu: but as for the rest, I shall, I say no more, I shall —

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.p: How now, Core? how can you answer your being a tippling, when you should stand sentinel?

sp.speaker: Core.
sp.p: Believe me, captain, I had but a whiff or two: for I was passing dry.

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.p: Thou art always dry: the whoreson malt-worm has a throat like the burning climb, or a glass-makers furnace: but your remove from thence has saved you from the bolts. How now, what water-spaniel have we here?

sp.speaker: Core.
sp.p: 'Tis lieutenant nod.

sp.speaker: Nod.
sp.p: Captain, deride me not: I protest, I came by this mischance by good service, by following a spy, that came to discover our army.

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.p: O notable rogue! did not I find thee asleep, and threw thee into a ditch?

sp.speaker: Nod.
sp.p: Was't you? by this light, I took you for a spy.

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.p: Yet saw me not, no more than a molewarp: this is an egregious rogue.

sp.speaker: Nod.
sp.p: Yes, I saw you well enough, and I did but try how you would use me.

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.p: By this flesh and blood, many one that lies in his grave, was not half so senseless: but the watch breaks up, every one to his quarter, away.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: 'Tis true, they are gone together, and I am sent to watch prince Ferdinand, and the Earl of Pembroke: this way they went; but they are got out of sight. I were very bad to be a hound, that have no better a sent: if they were hares, as they are men, I should think them squatted: but hushed, here comes one of them.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: The morn look red: red morns do threat a storm,
That storm shall light on Pembroke or myself.
This is our meeting place: here runs the stream
That parts our camps: the time consorts the place;
And (Pembroke) it thy reputation hold,
It is thy q. to enter.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Here comes the tother, this is luck upon luck: now will I run and fetch my mistress, the lady Katharine, to part their fray.

sp.speaker: Pem.
sp.l: Good end succeed my early heaviness:
Three times my feet, as loath to guide me hither,
Have stumbled in a plain and even way,
My sword forsook his scabbard once or twice,
Blood from my nostrils thrice hath spouted forth,
And such a dimness overruns my sight,
That I have ta'en a tree to be a man,
And questioned with it about serious things.
This is the place where I must meet my friend.
Yonder he stands. Good morrow, Ferdinand.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Good morrow to thy death: draw, Pembroke, draw, the ground thou treadest upon, must be thy grave.

sp.speaker: Pem.
sp.p: Draw upon Ferdinand?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Ay, upon me.
sp.l: Dally not, Pembroke, I am bent to fight,
And that with thee for the best blood thou bearest.

sp.speaker: Pem.
sp.p: You have some reason for this resolution.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: My will.

sp.speaker: Pem.
sp.l: A sorry argument to kill your friend.
I must have better reason than your will,
Or I'll not draw upon my Ferdinand:
Our love is older than of one day's growth,
A years continuance hath united us.
Have we not made an interchange of oaths,
Sworn love to one another twenty times,
Confirmed that friendship by society,
Increased it with the sympathy of mind,
Making one pleasure, pleasure unto both?
And shall this bond be broken upon will?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Then you'll not draw?

sp.speaker: Pem.
sp.l: Yes, nearer to thy person,
In friendly sort to embrace thee, Ferdinand.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Thou art a coward, and thou dar'st not fight.

sp.speaker: Pem.
sp.l: Thou knowest the contrary: for we have fought
At every weapon, to approve our skill.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Go to, you are a villain and a coward,
And by the royal blood that gave me life,
I'll kill thee, Pembroke, though thou do not draw.

sp.speaker: Pem.
sp.l: Kill me? thou wilt not wrong thine honour so?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Zounds, but I will: and traitor, take thou that.

sp.speaker: Pem.
sp.l: Wound me so desperately? nay then I'll draw,
Not to offend, but to defend myself.
Now I perceive it is my blood thou seekst:
Witness you heavens, and all you gracious powers,
That stand auspicious to this enterprise,
That Pembroke draws forth an unwilling sword.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Why so, now manfully defend thyself.

sp.speaker: Pem.
sp.l: Another wound? then Pembroke, rouse thy spirit,
And bear no longer with this harebrained man.
Yet (Ferdinand) resolve me of the cause,
That moves thee to this unkind enterprise:
And if I satisfy thee not in words,
This double wound shall please thee with my blood.
Nay, with my sword I'll make a score of wounds,
Rather than want of blood divorce thy love.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: I hate thee deadly, and I seek thy life:
What other reason, Pembroke, wouldst thou have?
Prepare, prepare, in this conflict to show,
Thou art a knight, and canst o'ercome thy foe.

sp.speaker: Pem.
sp.l: And if I spare thee not, impute the cause
To thine own rashness, and mine aching wounds.

div.stage: Fight, and hurt each other, both fall down as dead.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: I hope I have slain thee.

sp.speaker: Pem.
sp.l: O, I fear thy life: how fares my Ferdinand?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: What, liv'st thou yet? than my fare is ill.

sp.speaker: Pem.
sp.l: I am marked for death,
I feel a general faintness through my limbs:
Expense of blood will soon expend my life.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: The like debility my joints do feel.

sp.speaker: Pem.
sp.l: Then we must both die in the latest of death.
Tell me, o tell me, whence proceeds this hate?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: I fear not (Pembroke) to discover now.
Thou wert my spokesman unto Katharine,
And treacherously thou stolest away her heart.
O, I can say no more, my spirits do faint.
Pembroke, farewell, I have revenged my wrong.

sp.speaker: Pem.
sp.l: O ▪ yet a little longer, gracious time,
Detain his princely spirit in his breast,
That I may tell him he is misinformed,
And purge myself unto my dying friend:
But death hath laid his numb-cold hand upon me:
I am arrested to depart this life.
Dear Ferdinand, although thou be my death,

div.stage: On thee I'll friendly breathe my latest breath. Enter Forrester.

sp.speaker: Forester
sp.l: How full of pleasure is this forest life!
My park I liken to a common wealth,
In which, my bucks and does are citizens:
The hunter's lodge, the court, from whence is sent
Sentence of life or death, as please the King:
Only our government's a tyranny,
In that we kill our subjects upon sport.
But stay, what gentlemen do here lie slain?
If any spark of life do yet remain,
I'll help to fan it with a nimble hands
The organ of his arm doth play apace,
He is not so far spent, but that with help,
He may recover to his former state.
How is the other? I do feel soft-breath
Break from between his lips. O, for some aid,
To bear them to the forest, to my lodge:
But as I am, I'll try my utmost strength,
To save their lives: first seen, shall be the first:
Patience, and I'll return and fetch the other.

sp.speaker: Fisherman
sp.l: My angle-rod is broke, my sport is done;
But I will fetch my net, to catch some fish:
To lose both fish and pleasure, is too much.
O what contentment lives there in the brook!
What pretty trames are made by cunning hands,
To entrap the wily watery citizens!
But what art thou that liest upon the ground?
Sleepest thou? or art thou slain? hath breath his last?
No spark of life appears: yet from his eye,
Methinks I see a glimmering light break-forth,
Which wanting strength, is like a twilight glimpse.
If there be any hope to save his life,
I'll try my utmost cunning, to my house,
Poor gentleman, I'll bear thee as a guest,
And either cure thy wounds, or make thy grave.

div.stage: Enter Forrester, missing the other taken away, speaks any thing, and exit.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Just in this circle I left the two princes ready to draw; for I read the whole discourse of the combat in their red eyes.

sp.speaker: Kath.
sp.p: Here lie their weapons, and here flows their blood.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Have they not slain one another, and buried themselves?

sp.speaker: Kath.
sp.p: Peace, fool ▪ 'tis too sure, that they are slain.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: O lord, then let me turn myself into a ballad, and mourn for them.

sp.speaker: Kath.
sp.l: Thou anger'st me, with jesting at my sorrow:
Hence from my sight, my heart is full of grief,
And it will break, the burden is so great.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Go from your sight? then let me go out of your company: for I had as lief leave your sight as your company. Is this my reward for watching and watching? O mistress, do not kill me with unkindness: I shall, I shall —

sp.speaker: Kath.
sp.p: What shall you?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: Weep out mine eyes, and fill the holes with salt water.

sp.speaker: Kath.
sp.l: I prithee leave me, I am not displeased,
But fain would vent my sorrow from my heart.
Hold, take my purse, spend that, and leave my presence:
Go everywhere , inquire my Pembroke out:
And if thou bringst meto his breathless trunk.
I will reward thee with a treble gift.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Well, I were best be going, now I am so fairly offered. Mistress, your reward hath stopped my tears, and enticed my legs to be walking. Farewell, I will go, God knows whither, to seek and to find both, and neither. Farewell, sweet mistress.

sp.speaker: Kath.
sp.l: O Pembroke, let me kneel unto thy blood:
And yet I know not whether't be thy blood,
save that my soul by a divine instinct,
Tells me it is the treasure of thy veins.
If thou beest dead, thou mirror of all men,
I vow to die with thee: this field, this grove
Shall be my receptacle till my last:
Content with that that feeds the airy souls,
My pillow shall be made a bank of moss,
And what I drink, the silver brook shall yield.
No other camp nor court will Katharine have,
Till fates do limit her a common grave.

div.stage: Enter France, Navar, Philip, Flaunders, Thomasin, and attendants.

sp.speaker: Nau.
sp.l: Our daughter fled! when? whither? which way? how?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: I know not.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Bellamira, my life's joy,
Upon those pinionw that support her flight,
Hovers my heart, you bear away my soul.
Turn, turn again, and give this earthly frame
Essential power, which for thine absence dies:
Thou art the sweet of sweets, the joy of joys:
For thee was Philip born. O turn again,
And Philip is the blessedest of men.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: We are glad she's gone, though we dissemble it.
Son, bridle this affection, cease these laments,
She did not value them.

sp.speaker: Nau.
sp.l: Lewes, she did,
Till savage hate that shape disfigured.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: O, she was worthy to be Queen of heaven.
Her beauty, ere it suffered violence,
Was like the sun in his meridian throne,
Too splendent for weak eyes to gaze upon.
She was too bright before, till being hid
Under that envious cloud, it took the place
Of a dark ground, to show a lovelyer face.
That leprosy in her seemed perfect beauty:
and she did gild imperfections her.
With virtue, which no foul calumnious breath
Could ever soil, true virtues die is such,
That malice cannot stain, nor envy touch.
Then say not but her worth surmounts these woes.

sp.speaker: Nau.
sp.l: She grieved to tie you to a hated bed,
And therefore followed Burbon for revenge.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Burbon? who names him? that same verbal sound
Is like a thunder clap to Philip's ears,
Frighting my very soul. Sure, you said, Burbon,
And to that prodigy you joined revenge:
Revenge, that like a shadow follows him.
'Twas he that made me bankrupt of all bliss,
Sued the divorce of that pure white and red,
Which decked my Bellamira's lovely cheeks:
And shall he scape unpunished?

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Join your hands,
And all with us swear vengeance on the Duke.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Not for the world: who prosecutes his hare
On Burbon, injures me: I am his foe,
And none but I will work his overthrow.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: What means our son?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: To hunt him for revenge.
The darkest angle of this universe,
Shall not contain him through the bounded world:
I'll prosecute his flight with ceaseless steps:
And when long travel makes them dull or faint,
Baiting them fresh with Bellamira's wrongs,
Like eagles they shall cut the flaxen air,
And in an instant bring me where he is.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Where goes our son?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: To hell, so that in that kingdom,
Fate would ascertain me to meet with Burbon.
Wherever I confront him, this shall kill him.

sp.speaker: Nau.
sp.l: Thou shalt have aid to compass thy revenge ▪

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: No aid, but this strong arm. Farewell, farewell.
Since Bellamira hath for sooke her friend,
I seek destruction (Burbon) and mine end

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Stay him: this fury will betray thy life.

sp.speaker: Nau.
sp.l: Poor King made wretched by thy daughter's loss.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Poor King made wretched by thy desperate son.

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.l: Spend not your woes too fast, but save some tears
To dew the obsequies of your dead son.

sp.speaker: Nau.
sp.l: What, Ferdinand?

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.l: He's slain by Pembroke's hands,
And Pembroke left breathless by Ferdinand.
Their quarrel is uncertain, and their bodies
By some uncivil hands contrayed away,
And no inquiry can discover them.

sp.speaker: Nau.
sp.l: Our son slain ▪ Bellamira poisoned ▪
Navarre, tear off these hairs, and raging die.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: More tragedies at hand, what news brings Roderick?

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Such as will make the hearers, senseless trunks.
Why do thy our highness in your foemen's tents
Revel away the time, and yield your person,
To the known malice of your enemies,
Whilst in your own tents, rapine and foul lust,
Grasps your fair daughter to dishonour her?

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Our daughter?

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: She is slily stolen from thence,
Yet none knows whither, save one sentinel,
Who doth report he heard a wretched lady
Exclaim, false Ferdinand would ravish her.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: That was my child dishonoured by thy son.

sp.speaker: Nau.
sp.l: You wrong him, France.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Thou hast betrayed us, King,
And trained us to a loathed festival,
The marriage of thy stained and leprous child,
Whilst in our absence, Ferdinand unjust,
Hath stained our daughter's beauty with vild lust.

sp.speaker: Flaun.
sp.l: If you remember, he and English Pembroke
Last day forsook your camp, as discontent.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: That proved their loves were feigned, and of set malice,
He came to view our camp, how he might act
That deed of obloquy, and scape with life.

sp.speaker: Nau.
sp.l: 'Tis France hath done the wrong: you have commenced
This deed of death on Pembroke and our son;
And now to cover it, suggest and fain
Our guiltless son a guilty ravisher:
But render me their bodies.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Where's our child?

sp.speaker: Nau.
sp.l: Seek her.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Seek Ferdinand.

sp.speaker: Nau.
sp.l: France.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Petty King,
For this our wrong, look to be underling.

sp.speaker: Nau.
sp.l: What drum is this?

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Are we entrapped, Navarre?

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Fear not, on yonder hill, whose lofty head
O'erlooks the under-valleyes, royal Burbon,
Attended by ten thousand soldiers,
Craves peace and fair accord with mighty France.

sp.speaker: Nau.
sp.l: Burbon, that was the ruin of my child?
Summon our forces straight and charge the slave,

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: In Bourbon's rescue draw our forces up.

sp.speaker: Nau.
sp.l: What means the King of France?

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: To join with him.

sp.speaker: Nau.
sp.l: What? with a traitor and a murderer

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: He did a deed of merit and of fame,
Poisoned the sister of a ravisher,
A Tarquin, an incestuous Tereus,
And our poor child the wronged Philomell:
Arraign our battles straight, and join with Burbon.

sp.speaker: Nau.
sp.l: Hear what we'll urge.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Speak then in war and death:
In other terms, out rage will spend no breath.

sp.speaker: Nau.
sp.l: And we will speak so loud, that heaven itself
Shall echo with the clangor: both our children
We'll raze from our remembrance, and advance
no other thought, but how to plague proud France.
Conjoin with Burbon, ere three suns shall set,
In the vast kingdom of Oreanus:
In a pitched field we'll meet the King of France,
And that false traitor Duke.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Navarre, thou dar'st not.

sp.speaker: Nau.
sp.l: Now by saint Denis, and our grandsire's tomb,
We'll meet thee.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Welcome. O, bring valiant men.
We'll think on naught but graves and tombs till then.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Ha, ha: I laugh to see these Kings at jar.
Now civil discord like a raging flood,
Swelling above her banks, shall drown this land,
Whilst Rodorick on her ruins builds his hopes.
The King of France through my suggestion,
Thinks Katharine his daughter ravished,
Who only winged with love, is fled the camp:
Pembroke and Ferdinand, in mutual strife,
Slain by each other, doth confirm my words ▪
And for revenge whets keen the two Kings swords.

div.stage: Enter Pembroke armed, and the forester.

sp.speaker: Pem.
sp.l: I thank thee, forester, whose rough grown walks,
Wild in aspect, afford more courtesy,
Than places smoother for civility.
My life redeemed by thy industrious hand,
Remains in love and duty bound to thee.

sp.speaker: Forester
sp.l: Fair knight, prevention of sad death, by health,
More joys my soul, than thanks or rich reward.
But is your armour easy? sits it well?

sp.speaker: Pem.
sp.l: I never in my life was better fitted.
This should be that unlucky fatal place,
Where causeless hate drew blood from Ferdinand.
Behold the grass, a purple register,
Still blusheth in remembrance of our fight.
Why wither not these trees? those her be and plants?
And every neighbour branch drop out their grief?
Poor souls, they do, and have wept out their sap,
Yet I have paid no duty to my friend.
Where is the tomb I willed you to erect?

sp.speaker: Forr.
sp.l: See, valiant knight, proportioned and set up,
As well as my poor skill would suffer me:
And here his picture hangs.

sp.speaker: Pemb.
sp.l: You have done well:
Your hand I see's a perfect architect
In sorrow's building: once more let suffice
I quite your painful travel but with thanks:
Now leave me to myself, for here I vow
To spend the remnant of my hapless days:
No knight nor prince shall ever pass this way,
Before his tongue acknowledge Ferdinand
The faithfullest lover and the lovingest friend
The world contains: I'll have his sepulchre
As yet but naked and ungarnished,
Ere many days hang richer with the spoils
And vanquished trophies of proud passengers,
Then was the Romans wealthy Capitol:
So, gentle forester, bequeath thy prayers
In my assistance; that is all I crave.

sp.speaker: Forr.
sp.l: The god of power give power unto your arm,
That you may prove victorious fortunate.

sp.speaker: Pem.
sp.l: Farewell, kind host: and now let me embrace
This empty monument of my lost friend.
Oh! were't so happy to enshrine his bones,
How blessed should Pembroke be? but they are torn
By the fierce savage wolf, whose filthy maw
Is made an unfit grave to bury him.
But if (Without offence) I may desire it,
I wish his soul from paradise may see,
How well his name is kept in memory:
These eyes that saw him bleed, have wept for him:
This heart devised his harm, hath sighed for him:
And now, this hand, that with ungentle force
deprived his life, shall with repentant service,
Make treble satisfaction to his soul ▪
Fortune, thou dost me wrong, to suffer me
So long uncombatted: I prithee send
Some stubborn knight, some passenger,
Whose stout controlling stomach will refuse
To yield to my prescription, but by force ▪
I hate this idle rest of precious time.
How now! deridest thou my devotion, goddess?
Thou sendest a woman to encounter me.
Henceforth I'll hold thee for a feigned name,
And no disposer of my Christian hopes:
But soft, I know that face: o! Ay, 'tis she
Was unjust cause of all this misery.

sp.speaker: Kath.
sp.l: Long have I wandered with unquiet mind,
To find my Pembroke: that they fought, I hear:
That they were wounded both to death, I hear:
But whether cured or dead, I cannot hear ▪
Nor lives there any (If deceased) can tell,
Within what place their bodies are interred.
Since therefore all my travel is in vain,
Here will I take a truce with former care.
This cursed nook was that unlucky plot,
Where cursed Ferdinand did kill my love.
What knight is this? I'll question him, perhaps
He can resolve me where my Pembroke is:
Joy and good fortune, sir, attend your state.

sp.speaker: Pem.
sp.l: Your wishes come too late.
What seek you, madam?

sp.speaker: Kath.
sp.l: Tell me, sir knight, for so you seem to be:
Know you this dismal place you do frequent?
Or have you heard of that unhappy fight,
Was here performed by Pembroke and his foe?

sp.speaker: Pem.
sp.l: Yes, madam, I have heard of it long since,
And, to my grief, knew both the gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.l: But can you tell me if they live or no?
Or dead, what hand hath given them burial ▪

sp.speaker: Pem.
sp.l: Rest you assured, madam, they are dead:
The one of them to whom I was allied,
And nearly knitted in friendship from my youth,
By me lies buried here: a braver knight,
And truer lover never breathed in France.

sp.speaker: Kath.
sp.l: O tell me, is it Pembroke? if for him
You have erected this fair monument,
Perpetual honour I will do your state:

sp.speaker: Pem.
sp.l: Not only, madam, have I built this tomb
In his memorial: but myself have sworn
Continual residence within this wood:
And for the love I bore him, wear these arms,
That whatsoever knight, adventurer or other,
Making his journey this way, and refusing
To do knight's homage to my breathless friend,
By this assayling steel may be compelled.

sp.speaker: Kath.
sp.l: O, let me know your name, so kindly moved,
To dignify my Pembroke's high deserts.

sp.speaker: Pem.
sp.l: You did not hear me say 'twas Pembroke, madam ▪
What is become of him, I do not know,
Nor greatly care, since he did wrong my friend,
And first enkindled this dissentious brawl.
This buried here, is noble Ferdinand,
His father's comfort, and his country's hope.
O madam! had you seen him as I did,
Begirt with wounds, that like so many months,
Seemed to complain his timeless overthrow:
And had before been inward with his virtues,
To think that nature should endure such wrack,
And at one time so many precious gifts
Perish by death, would have dissolved your heart.
He was the very pride of fortitude,
The house of virtue, and true friendship's mirror:
Look on his picture, in the arms of death,
