When he was ready to give up the ghost,
I caused it to be drawn: if at that time,
In that extremity of bitter pangs,
he looked so lovely, had so fresh a colour,
So quick a moving eye, so red a lip,
What was his beauty when he was in health?
See with what courage he endured the combat,
Smiling at death for all his tyranny.
Had death been ought but what he was, stern death,
He would have been enamoured with his look.

sp.speaker: Kath.
sp.l: A certain soft remorse
Creeps to my heart, persuades me he was true,
Loving, and virtuous: but myself unkind,
Coily to scorn the proffer of his mind.

sp.speaker: Pem.
sp.l: O that in justice of her former hate,
She now would hopeless dote on Ferdinand ▪
I'll do the best I can to bring her on:
Despair and madness, fetch her off again,
Madam, how say you? wast not a grievous thing,
So rich a gem, should lie raked up in dust?
So sweet a flower, be withered in his prime?

sp.speaker: Kath.
sp.l: Death was a villain for attempting it,
And so was Pembroke for effecting it.
No bloody Scythian, or inhumane Turk,
But would ha' trembled to ha' touched his skin,
Or spilt one drop of his heroic blood.

sp.speaker: Pem.
sp.l: Had not that lady then an iron heart?
A rude ingrateful mind? A savage spirit?
That knew this virtuous honourable knight,
This gracious shape, and unmatched excellence,
To be entangled with her ferment love,
To serve her in all loyalty of heart,
To reverence and adore her very name,
To be content to kiss the lowly earth,
Where she did set her foot: and when he sued
For grace, to scorn him, to deride his sighs ▪
And hold his tears and torment in contempt ▪
Of all that ever lived, deserved she not,
The world's reproach, and times perpetual blot?

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.l: Herded you him ever speak of such a one?

sp.speaker: Pem.
sp.l: Oft times: but chiefly then, when he perceived,
His hurt was mortal, and no way but death.
At every groan, he called upon her name,
As if that sound were present remedy?
And when insulting death drew short his breath,
And now was ready to close up his eyes:
Farewell, quoth he, where'er I find a shrine,
My soul fly thou to beauteous Katharine.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.l: That ruthless mind, that iron savage heart,
So greatly loved, and so little loving,
Breathes in this breast, 'twas I returned disdain,
For deep affection; scorn for loyalty:
And now compassionless shall pine myself.
O Ferdinand, forgive me, Ferdinand:
Enjoin me any penance for that wrong;
Say I shall tread a tedious pilgrimage
To furthest Palestine, and I will do it.
But peace, fond woman, these exclaims are vain?
Thy Ferdinand is dead and cannot hear,
As thou wast sometimes deaf, and wouldst not hear.

sp.speaker: Pemb.
sp.l: A just reward. Come, madam, have you done?
Give me the picture I may hang it up.

sp.speaker: Kath.
sp.l: O take it not away: since I have lost
The substance, suffer me to keep the shadow:
Methinks , so long as this is in my hand,
I clasp my Ferdinand between mine arms:
So long as I behold this lively form,
So long as I refreshed by his smiles:
So long, methinks , I hear him speak to me.
Knew I the painter drew this counterfeit,
I would reward him with a mint of gold.

sp.speaker: Pem.
sp.l: If such a pleasure you receive by this,
I tell you, madam, I shall shortly have
His whole proportion cut in alabaster,
Armed as he was when he encountered here,
Which kneeling, shall be set upon his tomb.

sp.speaker: Kath.
sp.l: On that condition I will gather flowers,
and once a day come straw them at his feet:
And once a day pay tribute of choice thanks ▪
To you the furtherer of my happiness:
Till then, I place the picture where it was.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Come on, madam, methinks now a mask would do well: but I perceive your drift, I smell your policy, you think a bald face hath no need of a black mask. Shall I tell you what you look like? A broiled herring, or a tortured image made of plaster work.

sp.speaker: Bel,
sp.l: So, sirrah, you may scoff my misery.

sp.speaker: Pem.
sp.l: Still haunted with these women? are men vanished?
Or what occasion leaves the realm of France,
So void and empty of adventurous knights?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: Out of peradventure, madam, the ghost of saint
George is come out of England, to see what hospitality s.
Denis keeps in France.

sp.speaker: Pem.
sp.l: Poor Bellamira, I lament thy state;
But I must still suppress my discontent.
What are you so deformed with loathsome spots?
And what that antic keeps you company?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Antic! thou liest, and thou wert a knight of gingerbread: I am no antic, the whole parish where I was born will swear, that since the reign of Charlemagne there was not a better face bred or brought up amongst them.

sp.speaker: Kath.
sp.l: Have patience, knight, however thus deformed,
This lady is the daughter of Navarre.
Madam, it joys me I have met you here,
Though much laments me of your heavy plight.
There needs no repetition of your wrong:
I know, the villain Burbon did the dead,
Whom my incensed brother will revenge.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: For Philip's sake I have been martyred thus,
And for his sake left King and courtly life,
To entertain a pilgrim's painful habit.
But on what strange adventure stays this knight,
within this desolate forsaken wood?

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.l: For love of Ferdinand your princely brother,
Whose hearse he guards in honourable arms.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Is this my brother's hearse? is this the place,
Where I was shipwrecked of a brother's name?
O, let me spend a loving sigh for him,
And sacrifice a sister's holy rites:
For ever rest, sweet Ferdinand, in peace,
Until thy body glorified from heaven,
Become immortal by thy soul's return.

sp.speaker: Pem.
sp.l: Poor Bellamira, how I pity thee ▪
Yet must forbear to comfort thy distress.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: Is my young lord buried here? I say no more, but
I pray God send him a joyful insurrection.

sp.speaker: Kath.
sp.l: Enough, sweet Bellamire,
These leprous spots, 'tis time they were removed.
Come, go with me. Since I left Aquitaine,
And came acquainted with these private walks,
It was my happy chance to meet an hermit,
Whose skill in physic warrants present cure,
And pure refining of your poisoned blood:
I'll bring you thither: afterwards select
Delicious sweets, to deck your brother's tomb.
Come, sirrah, follow us.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Do not think, madam, that I'll forsake you. And so, sir, you that walk in pewter vessel, like one of the worthies, will you be ruled by me?

sp.speaker: Pem.
sp.l: Wherein?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: To set a 'gin for woodcocks, and catch yourself first.

sp.speaker: Pem.
sp.l: Hence, beetlehead. And Pembroke, now bethink
How great a tide of miseries breaks in.
First, thou art taxed with the loss of him,
Whom equal with thyself thou holdest dear:
Next, Bellamira is become a leper,
Whose absence Philip carefully laments:
Then treacherous Burbon joins himself with France,
And both the Kings are angrily incensed:
but last, which is some comfort to the rest,
Disdainful Katharine wastes with fruitless love.
Would all so minded like mishap might prove.
But by this signal there are knights at hand,
I must provide their valours to withstand.

div.stage: Enter France, Burbon, Rodoricke, Peter de lions, at one door: at the other, Navar, Flaunders, Dick Bowyer, and soldiers, Pembroke between them.

sp.speaker: Pem.
sp.l: Stay your intended march.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: What peer of France,
Or in the world so haughty resolute,
Dare breathe the word of stay to mighty France?

sp.speaker: Na.
sp.l: Or what art thou presum'st to stay my course?

sp.speaker: Pem.
sp.l: A knight I am, and to adventures bound:
This monument erected for my friend,
By me is guarded: if you mean to pass,
You must do homage, or else fight with me.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.p: Homage of me! Know I am King of France, and in subjection to no earthly power.

sp.speaker: Nau.
sp.p: Thou knowest not what thou sayst, to challenge us, of any such inferior privilege.
sp.l: What homage is it thou requirest of us?

sp.speaker: Pem.
sp.l: First, to acknowledge him lies buried here,
The faithfulst lover, and most valiant knight,
That in this time drew sword, or managed horse.

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.p: And what was he? A scapart, or your countryman Gargantua, that stuffed every button of his coat with a load of hay? 'sheart, we have me a fellow; here's all mouth, he speaks nothing but monarch. Dost thou hear, King? give me leave to encounter this puckfist: and if I do not make him cry peccavi, say Dick bowyer's a powdered mackerel.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: My blood begins to boil, I could be pleased,
to have this fellow by the ears, but that
There's many of my betters here in place.

sp.speaker: Fland.
sp.l: King of Navarre, let Flanders cope with him.

sp.speaker: Burb.
sp.l: Imperial France, give Burbon leave to try
The hazard of a combat with this boaster.

sp.speaker: Pem.
sp.l: Dispatch, Navarre, one of you come forth,
To interchange a warlike blow or two.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: First let us know what penalty thou setst
Upon thyself, if thou be vanquished.

sp.speaker: Pem.
sp.l: A recantation of my former words,
A servitude to him that conquers me:
But whosoever is by me subdued,
Must leave his shield to beautify this shrine.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: Let not Navarre, my lord, rob us of honour:
Say, Burbon first shall break a lance with him.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: A scribe that privilege, my lord, to me:
And Rodorick will have death, or victory.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: No, noble Rodorick, Burbon shall begin,
And as he speeds, we will employ your power.

sp.speaker: Pem.
sp.l: Provide thee, Burbon, I'll not favour thee.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: Be sure he show thee like hostility.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Hold, the advantage is on thy side,
The Duke of Burbon shall hang up his shield.

sp.speaker: Pem.
sp.l: I'd rather have his life, than all your shields:
Who is next?

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.p: Zounds, I think he has a patten to take up all the shields ith' country, hang me if thou wantest work, here's for Navarre, the Earl of Pembroke and cavaliero Bowyer:(Fighta thousand pound to a tailor's bodkin, this fellow has a familiar: but howsoever, thou mayst thank my lame leg: there's my shield.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Now Rodorick, betake you to your task.

sp.speaker: Rodor.
sp.l: My fortune's answerable to the rest.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Since all miscarry, France will put his chance
Upon the hazard of the dice for once.

sp.speaker: Pem.
sp.l: You are an honourable foe, my lord:
By law of arms, you must hang up your shield.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: I yield to law and thy approved valour.
King of Navarre, will only you sit out?

sp.speaker: Nau.
sp.l: No, King of France, my blood's as hot as thine,
And this my weapon shall confirm my words.

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.l: Navarre down too! 'sheart, this fellow hath the trick of it:
If he be not a witch or some devil, let me be
Sticked into a carbinado.

sp.speaker: Nau.
sp.l: Thou son of chivalry, let me now entreat,
To know his name, for whom thou reap'st this honour:
Or what he was, whose body's here interred?

sp.speaker: Pem.
sp.l: A valiant knight, his name, young Ferdinand,
Slain by misfortune of a friendly hand.

sp.speaker: Nau.
sp.l: Is it my son thou mak'st thy valour's prize,
And strivest so to eternize with thy sword?
Let me embrace thee. Not alone my shield,
But I will leave my heart upon his shrine.
My dearest Ferdinand, I would my sighs,
Or sad lamenting tears might have the power,
Like balm to quicken thy benumbed joints,
Then would I drown this marble ere I went,
And heat it hot with vapour of my breath.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Navarre, this now may testify thy wrong,
In false accusing me for his remove.

sp.speaker: Na.
sp.l: Thou mayst be guilty still for ought I know:
For though I find him dead, I find not yet
The tragic manner of his hapless end.
Thou mayst as well have murdered Ferdinand,
As favour him hath poisoned Bellamira.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Injurious King, it was base Ferdinand,
On whom just heavens have shown just vengeance here,
Ravished my Katharine and conveyed her hence,
Where I shall never more behold her face.

sp.speaker: Nau.
sp.l: 'Tis false, and we'll maintain it with our swords ▪

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: 'Tis true, and we'll maintain it with our swords.

sp.speaker: Pem.
sp.l: By heaven, the tongue profanes the sacred name
Of Ferdinand with any villainy,
I'll cut it out, or stop his throat with blood,
And so dam in his blasphemous upbraids.

sp.speaker: Nau.
sp.l: Content thee, knight, I'll case thee of that labour.
Tomorrow is expired the time of truce.
France, on with thy battalions to the plain
Thou wast prepared before to pitch upon,
I'll meet thee there.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: And I will meet with thee.
Sound drums and trumpets: honoured knight, farewell:
Who shall survive next morn, strange news shall tell.

sp.speaker: Pem.
sp.l: Thus heady rage, blind in her rash resolve
Drew Ferdinand and me into the field,
As now it doth these hot incensed Kings.
Were't not my vows prohibit my desire,
To stay the inconvenience of this fight,
I would discover where their daughters are,
To show the error they are shrouded in:
But time hath run a desperate course with me,
And desperate let them run to misery:
Here comes a straggler of their army ▪ stand.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: What voice is that presumes to bid me stand?

sp.speaker: Pem.
sp.l: His that can force thee, if thou wilt not stand.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: By this bright air reflecteth on my sword,
If the whole army of Navarre had said
As much to Philip, yet he would not stand.
And thou but one, how dar'st thou proffer it,
Knowing how sharp a spur doth prick me on,
The death of Burbon for my Bellamire?

sp.speaker: Pem.
sp.l: Hang up thy shield, as other knights have done,
Upon the hearse of noble Ferdinand,
And thou mayest freely pass without control.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: The hearse of Ferdinand! I honour him,
He was the brother of my dearest love,
What's this I see? my father's battered shield!
The shield of France! of Flanders! Bourbon's too!
It can not then impeach or prejudice
The name of Philip, to consort with such,
Especially being done for Ferdinand.
There is my shield: and knight, but for my haste,
I would expostulate of other things:
But after traitorous Burbon I have slain,
Knight, look for me, I'll visit thee again.
Now Rodorick, keep thy word, and I am blessed:
But if thou fail, I'll forward with the rest.

sp.speaker: Pem.
sp.l: Successful action sit upon thy sword:
This net of sorrows, I perceive, entangles
Not only Pembroke, but the court of France.
Navarre and his associates are all touched.
Time look upon us, and at last determine,
This heart-dissevering tumults with a peace.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Since, Ferdinand, by gracious providence,
Thou art recovered of thy mortal wounds;
With the new life thy body is revived,
Revive the ancient passions of thy mind,
Think on thy friend, on Pembroke take remorse,
Whose honoured life, thy hasty hand cut off:
This is the place, as I remember me.
What's here? A tomb? who hath prevented me
In my religious duty to my friend?
You, knight, I doubt not, can resolve me.

sp.speaker: Pem.
sp.l: What art thou? stand.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: A knight, and fain would know,
What sacred monument and tomb this is?

sp.speaker: Pem.
sp.l: His, whilst he lived, that of the world's increase,
Was the most loyal friend, and valiant knight:
Which thou must likewise ratify with me,
And hang thy shield up to adorn his hearse,
Or venture combat for denying it.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: His name, I pray thee.

sp.speaker: Pem.
sp.l: Ferdinand.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: What's he acquainted with my name? belike some one
loved Pembroke, and supposing (Wrongfully)
Me slain by him, to satisfy for that,
Observes this honour in my memory:
Be not thou Ferdinand ingrateful then,
But stand for Pembroke, as this knight for thee.

sp.speaker: Pem.
sp.l: What answer givest thou? shall I homage have?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Not for his sake thou namest, not for Ferdinand:
There lived a knight excelled his petty fame,
As far as costly pearl the coursest pebble:
An English knight called Pembroke, were his bones
Interred here, I would confess of him
Much more than thou requirest, and be content
To hang both shield and sword upon his hearse.

sp.speaker: Pem.
sp.l: How comes this stranger by my name? Belike
He was affected unto Ferdinand:
And for his sake (Hearing he did me wrong)
Covets to make amends, or means to prove
If I embrace him with unfeigned love.
He shall not doubt of that, once more I say,
'Twas Ferdinand was the renowned knight
Of all the world.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: But I deny that saying,
Giving to Pembroke that pre-eminence.

sp.speaker: Pem.
sp.l: For Ferdinand my valour will I try.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: In Pembroke's valour I will fight and die.

sp.speaker: Pem.
sp.l: Either I dream, or this is Ferdinand.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: My sight deludes me, or stout Pembroke lives.

sp.speaker: Pem.
sp.l: Thrice happy honoured, I do embrace my friend.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Welcome, o welcome Pembroke, to mine arms,
Whom I imagined, death had ta'en from me.

sp.speaker: Pem.
sp.l: The like did I by princely Ferdinand:
But that he lives, my soul confounds with joy.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Tell me, dear friend, since our unlucky fight,
Have you heard ought of my disdainful love?

sp.speaker: Pem.
sp.l: Of her and all the rest: her father lives:
This is his shield, and this is great Navarre's:
this Rodorick's, the Duke of Orleans,
And this malicious Bourbon's: all the which
I forced from them, to beautify thy shrine.
But 'tis of Katharine thou desirest to hear:
She likewise hath been here; her flinty heart,
So much before inclined to cruelty,
Now waxeth tender: she no sooner saw
Thy picture here; but by heaven's providence,
Or how I know not, she so dotes on it,
As I supposed she would a died for love.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Has then my shadow and supposed death
Brought that to pass my living substance could not?

sp.speaker: Pem.
sp.l: It hath, and never lady more enamoured,
Then now is Katharine of her Ferdinand.
I told her, and no more than truth I told,
A cunning carver had cut out thy shape
And whole proportion in white alabaster,
Which I intended here should be set up.
She earnestly entreated she might have
A sight of it, and daily be permitted
To deck thy tomb and statue with sweet flowers.
She's but even now departed to that end,
And will (I know) be quickly here again.
Now for assurance I dissemble not,
Instead of thy resemblance cut in stone,
Kneel here thyself, and hear her piteous moan.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Content, I hold your counsel for the best:
We'll once conclude our sorrows with a jest.

sp.speaker: Pem.
sp.l: Soft, there's a cushion: nay, you must be bare,
And hold your hands up, as the manner is.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: What if I held a book, as if I prayed?

sp.speaker: Pem.
sp.l: 'Twere best of all; and now I think upon't,
Here is a book: so, keep your countenance,
You must imagine now you are transformed.
Yonder she comes, in any case stir not.

sp.speaker: Kath.
sp.l: I fear I have detracted time too long,
in my determined service to my love:
But I'll redeem my fault with double care.
See where his statue is set up: kind knight,
For ever Katharine will record thy truth.

sp.speaker: Pem.
sp.l: How say you, madam, is't not very like him?

sp.speaker: Kath.
sp.l: As like, as if it were himself indeed.
And would to God my prayers might be heard,
That as the image of Pygmalion once,
Life might descend into this senseless stone:
But that was feigned, as my desire is fond,
Relentless death withholds my Ferdinand;
And no entreaty may recover him.
In token then I do repent my scorn,
That I was cruel to so kind a friend,
Thou the presenter of his absent person,
Receive these sweets, thy temples be adorned
With this fresh garland; thy white ivory hand
Boast of this ring, which if thou wert alive,
Should bind our faiths up in a nuptial knot:
But for thou canst not be revived again,
I'll dwell with thee in death: and as my spirit
Mounts to the happy mansion of thy spirit:
So to accompany thy shadow here,
I'll turn my body to a shadow too;
And kneeling thus, confront thy silent looks,
With my sad looks: this is the instrument.
Now Ferdinand, behold thy Katharine comes.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: And she is welcome unto Ferdinand.

sp.speaker: Pem.
sp.l: I'll play the clerk for both, and say amen.
Nay, muse not, madam, 'tis no senseless image,
But the true essence of your wished love.

sp.speaker: Kath.
sp.l: I am ashamed to look him in the face.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Hide not those splendent lights, hereafter be
A constant wife, it shall suffice for me.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.l: Heaven cast her off, if Katharine prove not so.

sp.speaker: Pem.
sp.l: Of that no more: now let us haste from hence,
To quiet the dissension lately sprung
between your parents, Philip likewise gone,
To be revenged on Bourbon's treachery,
Perhaps may stand in need of friendly aid:
To him and them our vows must next be paid.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: What Pembroke counsels, we consent unto.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Now whilst our armies wearied with the heat
That the bright sun casts from his midday throne,
Abstain from bloody intercourse of war,
I'll lead thee Philip unto Bourbon's tent.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Roderick, thou highly favourest me in this,
And doubt not, if my complot take effect,
I'll make thee Duke of Burbon.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Stay your speech, here comes King Lewis.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: They can not know me, I am so disguised.

sp.speaker: Burb.
sp.l: Follow my counsel, and immediately begin the battle.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Why, the heat's great,
It burns in our armour as we march.

sp.speaker: Flan.
sp.l: It burns the enemy as well as we.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: It warms our soldiers spirits and makes them fire:
I had rather die, then when my blood is hot,
Be awed by counsel, till it freeze like ice:
He is no soldier, that for fear of heat,
Will suffer victory to fly the field.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: My lord of Burbon, ye are more hot than wise.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: Rodorick, methinks you are very peremptory.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: It is in zeal of the general good:
Go to your tent, refresh your unscorched limbs:
There draw your battles model: and as soon
As the cool winds have found the burning sun,
And made it tractable for travellers:
Arm you, and mount upon your barbed steed,
lead forth your soldiers, and in good array,
Charge bravely on the army of our foe.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: The Duke of Orleans hath counselled well,
I'll in and recreate me in my tent.
Farewell, my lord, when you resolve to fight,
Proclaim your meaning by a canon's mouth,
And with a volley I will answer you.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: If you will needs retire, farewell my lord.
Ha Roderick, are not we fine politicians,
That have so quaintly wrought the King of France
Unto our faction, that he threatens war,
Against the almost reconciled Navarre?

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: But this is nothing to the acts we'll do:
Come, come, my lord, you trifle time with words:
Sit down, sit down, and make your warlike plot:
But wherefore stand these murderous glaves so nigh?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Touch them not, Rodorick, prithee let them stand.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: Some paper, pen, and ink.

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.l: My lord.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: Post to the master gunner,
And bid him plant his demi culverings
Against the King's pavilion.

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.l: Presently.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: But first, bring pen and ink and paper straight.
Roderick, thou shalt assist me in this plot.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Do it yourself, my lord, I have a charge
Of soldiers, that are very mutinous,
And long I dare not stay, for fear my absence
Be cause of their revolt unto Navar.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: Then to your soldiers: I will to my plot.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Away my lord, leave me unto the Duke.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Kill you the Duke, and after I'll kill thee.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: This pen is stabbed, and it will not write,
The ink that's in the standage doth look black,
This in my pen is turned as red as blood.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: The reason that the platform you would make,
Must by this hand be written with thy blood.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: Zounds, what art thou that threatens Burbon so?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: One that's as desperate-careless of his life,
As thou art timorous, and fearest to die.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: Comest thou to kill me?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: If I should say no,
This weapon would condemn me, which I seized
Of purpose, Burbon, to bereave thy life.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: Why, fond man, mad man, knowest thou what thou dost?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I know it, Burbon, and I know besides,
What thou wouldst say, to daunt my resolution.

sp.speaker: Burb.
sp.l: What would I say?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Why, that this place is death,
As being thy tent, environed with thy slaves;
Where if I kill thee, 'tis impossible
To scape with life: this, Burbon, thou wouldst say:
But Philip is not to be moved with words.

sp.speaker: Burb.
sp.l: Philip!

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I Philip, Bellamira's love,
Whose beauty, villain, thou hast poisoned:
For which I have vowed thy death, and thou shalt die.
Therefore betake you to what fence you will,
Amongst this bundle choose one weapon forth,
And like a worthy Duke prepare thyself,
In knightly manner to defend thy life:
For I will fight with thee, and kill thee too,
Or thou shalt give an end unto my life.
But if thou call unto thy slaves for help,
Burbon, my sword shall nail thee to the wall ▪
And think prince Philip is a prince indeed,
To give thee this advantage for thy life.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: Boy, I will scourge your insolence with death.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Come on.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: O, I am slain.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Murder, murder, Burbon the Duke is slain.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Peace, Rodorick, I am Philip thy dear friend.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Thou art a counterfeit, I know thee not.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Didst not thou guide me unto Bourbon's tent?

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: I guide thee to the tent? I know thee not.
What, murder, ho: will no man hear my voice?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Yes, here are those can hear well enough.
Where is the murdered, and the murderer?

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Peter, behold thy masters breathless trunk,
And there's prince Philip that hath murdered him.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: To avoid prolixity, I'll kill him:
Yet first give me leave to weep for my master.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: First, seize the murderer, and after weep.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: He that first ventures to attach my life,
Let him be sure he hath a life to spare:
For I will send one breathless to the grave.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: You that have nine lives, assault the gentleman.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: What peasants, dare you not attach the slave?
I'll raise the whole camp, but I'll apprehend him.
Alarum drums: soldiers, encircle him,
And either apprehend or slay the wretch.

sp.speaker: Pem.
sp.l: 'Tis princely Philip, help to rescue him.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: What slaves are these that dare oppose themselves,
In rescue of a murderer 'gainst an host?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Such as will make thee, Rodorick, fly for life.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Zounds, men are mortal; to avoid prolixity, my
Lord of Orleans, your best course is flying, and therein I will be your follower.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Fly before three, and be thus strong?
'Twere madness.

sp.speaker: Pem.
sp.l: We trifle time, let's drive them from the tent.

div.stage: Alarum, and drive away Peter and Rodoricke.

sp.speaker: Pem.
sp.l: Live, worthy Philip, Pembroke bids thee live,
That did suspect this complot at the tomb,
When in the honour of prince Ferdinand,
You did resign your shield.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Th'earl of Pembroke!

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: And Ferdinand that loves thee as his soul.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Two lives I owe my stars, beside mine own,
In sending me two friends of such import.
Dared you adventure thorough the enemy's camp,
And put your lives in danger to save mine?

sp.speaker: Pem.
sp.l: The rumour of the Duke of Bourbon's death,
Hath so possessed the camp with admiration,
That they regardless suffer all to pass:
Only this, Rodorick wakens them a little;
But cannot wean them from their wondering minds.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: That Rodorick is a perfect villain turned:
For though he guided me unto his tent,
And gave his liking that the Duke should die;
Yet how the villain cried to murder me.
But come, in this confusion let's be gone,
'Tis dangerous to abide in Bourbon's tent.
Roderick, thou art the next must taste of death:
That task once done, we shall with little pain,
Our angry fathers reconcile again.

div.stage: Alarum, enter Navar, Bowyer, Nod, core, soldiers, drum and colours.

sp.speaker: Nau.
sp.l: The alarum sounded in the enemy's camp.
Now for Navarre and fame, stand to it, sirs.

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.p:
Heart, stand to it? here's some of us knows how to run away, and they be put to it: though we have lost our brave general, the Earl of Pembroke, ye
here's cavaliero Bowyer, Core and nod, by Jesu, sound cards; and Mahound and termagant come against us, we'll fight with them. Couragio, my hearts, s. George for the honour of England.

sp.speaker: Nau.
sp.p: The adverse part comes on, fight gallantly.

div.stage: Enter France, Flaunders, and soldiers, with drum and colours.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Is false Navarre so thirsty to drink blood,
That he must join the squadron of his troops,
Before the signal of the battle's given.
Belike you thought to take us unprepared.
No, King, our wrong hangs like a watch before us,
And makes us number every short-lived minute,
Till your life's answer for our daughter's death;
Charge, brave spirits: saint Denis now for France.

sp.speaker: Nau.
sp.l: Saint Denis for Navarre: alarum drums.

div.stage: Alarum, they fight, France put to the worst, enters Rodorike and Peter, the fight continued, and Navar driven in.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Navarre and his weak forces make retire:
Pursue them, sirs, the victory is ours.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Be like starved lions 'mongst a herd of beasts,
Ruthless and bloody slaughters all you meet,
Till proud Navarre be slain, or kiss your feet:
Saint Denis, and cry murder through the host.

div.stage: Alarum, enter Pembroke, Ferdinand and Philip.

sp.speaker: Pem.
sp.l: He that steps forward with a murdering thought,
Marries himself to death. France, cease the fight:
They are Frenchmen you pursue, French men you should save.
Dig not for traitors love your subjects grave.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: What frantic knights are those that dare oppose
their single force against our multitudes?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Those that wish you and France bright fame's increase.
So you would chase hence war, and welcome peace.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: That was the traitor, that slew royal Burbon.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Down with the villains.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Soldiers, seize on him,
And then pursue Navarre with sudden death.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Ere the least hair fall from his kingly head,
Rodorick, thy base trunk shall be butchered.

sp.speaker: Pem.
sp.l: Will you accept of peace?

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Follow Navarre.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Down with that murderer.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Zounds, then in spite,
We'll save Navarre, and chase you hence in fight.
All. Ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Pem.
sp.l: Nay, smile not, though our number's few,
Our great hearts tell us, we shall conquer you.
Alarum. and s. George.

div.stage: Alarum, they fight. Enter Navar and his forces: France chaste away.

sp.speaker: Nau.
sp.l: France and his daunted forces gives us ground:
Charge, charge again, and we are conquerors.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Stand, or never stir again.

sp.speaker: Nau.
sp.l: What mean these knights?

sp.speaker: Pem.
sp.l: To stop your passage this way, great Navarre.
I charge thee, by the duty of a King,
Thy love to justice, and thy subjects lives,
You sound retreat, and make a peace with France.

sp.speaker: Nau.
sp.l: A peace, and have the vantage of the day?

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.p: That's a trick, by Jesu, to mock an ape: we'll none of that.

sp.speaker: Nau.
sp.l: We'll have no peace, but what our swords can make.
Follow the chase.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Are you grown insolent?
For one light puff of fortune proves it so ▪
Nay, than our swords turn to your overthrow.

div.stage: Alarum, they fight, and drive in Navar.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: That was my father that you fought against.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: You did as much to mine.

sp.speaker: Pem.
sp.l: Princes, agree: force cannot end this war, but policy.
Therefore disperse yourselves, and let our squires,
With trumpets in their mouths sound loud retreat,
Where you perceive the fight most violent.
The strangeness of which act will straight amaze,
When they shall hear both peace and war denounced,
And one self instant, they will soon retire.
To know the issue, princes, fall to work:
'Tis work of charity, 'twould do me good,
If we could end this battle without blood.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: I hope we shall: farewell, I'll to my charge.

sp.speaker: Pem.
sp.l: The like will Pembroke.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Philip is not last.
Yet though I seek the safety of my friends,
Rodorick shall lose his blood, ere this fight ends.

div.stage: Alarum, excursions. Enter Peter leading Thomasin.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Struggle not, strive not, your sweet heart Bowyer cannot save you. Without prolixity, you must go with me.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Help, help.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: And the god of war come in thy defence, my humour is to kill him. Come away.

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.p:
By Jesu, and you go this way, you must pay custom. Zounds, you pickt-hatch cavaliero petticoat-monger, can you find time now to be catching Thomasin? come, deliver, or by Zenacrib, and the life of King Charlemagne, I'll thrash
your coxcomb, as they do hens at Shrovetyde: no, will you not do, you tan-fat? zounds, then have at you.

div.stage: They fight, Bowyer hath the wench, rescued by France, recovered by Navar: Philip meets Rodorick, rescued by Peter: retreat is sounded, the enemies begin to retire, Rodorick chased by Philip: enter at several doors, after retreat sounded, Pembroke and Ferdinand.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Are the Kings severed? will they bow to peace?

sp.speaker: Pem.
sp.l: Peace is a welcome guest unto their hearts:
But Roderick, like a greedy envious churl,
Fearing to spend his wealth, still keeps them back,
'Tis he exasperates the prince's hate:
And when our trumpets call them to retire,
He with war's clangor sets them on again.
Unless he be removed, our labour's lost.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: It shall not; for I'll seek him through the host,
And with this sword pare off the traitor's head.

sp.speaker: Pem.
sp.p: Do, and I'll scour these ranks: if Pembroke's eye encounters his, he meets his tragedy.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Stay, warlike friends, and aid me in revenge.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: That is Roderick.

sp.speaker: Pem.
sp.l: Here's the traitor, strike him down.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Who lifts his arm at him, strikes at my breast.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Why have you thus ringed me about with swords

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: To show thee thou must die.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: What have I done,
That thus you labour my destruction?

sp.speaker: Pem.
sp.l: Thou were't a party in all Bourbon's wrongs.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Falsely termed Ferdinand a ravisher.

sp.speaker: Pem.
sp.l: Set discord 'twixt these Kings,

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Practised my death.

sp.speaker: Pem.
sp.l: Villain, for this, our swords shall stop thy breath.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Stand not to argue, let's all run at him.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Now as you love my love, or prize mine honour.
Touch not the traitor, he is Philip's foe;
And none but I must work his overthrow.
Thrice in the battle he was rescued from me:
But now he's fallen into the lion's paw,
From whence the whole world cannot ransom him.
Preservers of my life, heroic friends,
Be you my safety, keep the soldiers off,
Whilst in the midst by fair and equal fight,
I send this traitor to eternal night.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: By heaven agreed.

sp.speaker: Pem.
sp.l: Here Pembroke takes his stand:
Come France and all the world, I will not start,
Till Philip's knightly sword pierce Rodorick's heart.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Accursed, I am betrayed, encompassed round:
Now life and hope and state must kiss the ground.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Rodorick, thou seest, all ways are stopped to fly,
Be desperate then, fight bravely, and so die.

div.stage: Alarum, they fight: enter to Pembroke Navar, Bowyer, and soldiers: to Ferdinand, France, Flaunders and soldiers: they fight and keep them back: Rodoricke would scape, still kept in the midst, and killed by Philip.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Now are his treacheries repaid with death:
Philip and Pembroke, sound your retreats
With better hope; in him all hatred ends:
The Kings will now love peace, and soon be friends.

div.stage: Exeunt. Enter Peter wounded, Bowier following.

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.p: Zounds, never run for the matter, a snatched face can not serve your turn, we must have bloody noses: stand on your guard: and I do not make haggis puddings of your guts, I'll never domineer in the long alleys again.

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.p: Cymnell, I'll crack you for this, I'll teach you to deal with Peter de lions, and that without prolixity.

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.l: Do: have at you in earnest: s. George, you rogue.

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.p: So, there's for your prolixities: there's for Thomasin: the thornbackly slave, and he were made of any thing but gristles, I am a pompion: 'sheart, he had no mettle in him: yet how the villain craked and domineered when he was living: ah, sirrah, never grin for the matter, 'tis captain Bowyer that speaks it. When thou meetest the great devil, commend me to him, and say, I sent him thee for a new years gift: and there's one Sarlaboys to, as arrant a bloodsucker, and as notable a coward, as ever drew weapon in a bawdy house: he carries my mark about him: if Dick Bowyer be not writ a bountiful benefactor in hell for my good deeds, in sending thither such cannibals, I am a rabbitsucker: yet I scorn to vaunt of my deeds too. They sound a retreat: farewell, Peter, and learn hereafter what it is to be rival to an English gentleman, cavaliero Bowyer, one of the nine worthies.

div.stage: A retreat. Enter at one door, France, Flaunders, and soldiers: at the other door Navar, Bowyer, and soldiers.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Navarre, why have you sounded a retreat?
Will your proud heart decline and call us lord?

sp.speaker: Nau.
sp.l: We thought by the faint language of your drums,
France would have known his error, and begged peace.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: France beg a peace!

sp.speaker: Nau.
sp.l: Navarre call you his lord!

sp.speaker: Flan.
sp.l: Why did you cease the fight, and sound retreat?

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.l: Not we, by this beard: not we, by the life of Pharo.

sp.speaker: Nau.
sp.l: Your trumpets guided by your fainting breath,
dehorted us from war, and sounded peace.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Navarre derides us.

sp.speaker: Nau.
sp.l: France, 'tis you that do't.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Sound war, and bravely let us once more to't.

div.stage: Enter in the midst, Pembroke, Ferdinand, and Philip.

sp.speaker: Pem.
sp.l: Kings of Navarre and France, why do you thus
With civil butchery wound this blessed land,
Which like a mother, from her melting eyes,
Sheds crimson tears, to see you enemies?
Lewes of France, wherein hath great Navarre
Dangered your state, that you should prosecute
War with her largest ruin? how hath France
Sowed such inveterate hate within your breast,
That to confound him, you will undergo
The orphans curse, the widow's tears and cries,
Whose husbands in these wars have lost their lives?
Ere you contend, discourse your grievances.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: False Ferdinand his son, ravished our child.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Now by my knighthood, honour, and this gage,
France, I'll approve you wrong that Ferdinand.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Who can accuse him?

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: That did Rodorick.

sp.speaker: Pem.
sp.l: That traitor, for a deed so false, so foul,
Hath answered it by this, even with his soul.

sp.speaker: Nau.
sp.l: Our son, and valour's bloom, th'english Pembroke,
By Lewes' treachery were butchered.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Were the whole world joined in so false a thing,
Alone I'd combat all, and clear the King.

sp.speaker: Pem.
sp.l: France never had design in their two deaths.

sp.speaker: Nau.
sp.l: He leagued with Burbon, that destroyed my child.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: He poisoned her deservedly.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: That deed of shame
Cut off his life, and razed out Bourbon's name.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: His death shall be thy death; for thy hand slew him.

sp.speaker: Nau.
sp.l: This other in the battle twice today,
made us retire, France, shall we join in league,
Till we have venged our malice on these knights?

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Navarre, agreed. Soldiers, this killed your lords.

sp.speaker: Nau.
sp.l: And this our fame: let's mangle them with swords.

sp.speaker: Pem.
sp.l: Take truce a while with rage: hear what we'll urge ▪
This knight flew Burbon, this enforced you fly;
Therefore you hate them, and for hate they die.
Since then true virtue is disfigured,
Desert trod down, and their heroic worth,
In justice doomed on traitor's merits, death:
Behold these two, which thousands could not daunt,
But your ungratitude, on bent knee,
Yield up their swords to bide your tyranny.
'Twas he killed Burbon: if you love him dead,
Show it by paring off this valiant head:
Do you the like: to this revenge apace.
They fear not threats, and scorn to beg for grace.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: And they shall find none.

sp.speaker: Nau ▪
sp.l: Knights, triumph in death,
We are your headsmen, Kings shall stop your breath.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Philip, my son!

sp.speaker: Nau.
sp.l: Young Ferdinand my joy!

sp.speaker: Pem.
sp.l: Call them not sons, whom you would fain destroy.

sp.speaker: Nau.
sp.l: Hold not our age too long in deep suspect.
Art thou Ferdinand?

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: And thou Philip?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: We are the friendly sons of adverse parents,
Your long lost children, though supposed slain,
We live, and come to joy your age again.

sp.speaker: Nau.
sp.l: Welcome all earthly bliss.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Welcome, dear child,
Thy presence half our sorrow hath exiled.

sp.speaker: Pem.
sp.l: How soon this scene is changed! those that e'en now
Were sworn wars servants, now to peace do bow:
Then Pembroke, strive to make their joys more full,
See, kingly father, to that princely son.
Pembroke, the hated murderer of his friend:
Pembroke, that did divide thee from his sight,
And cut so many passages of death,
In his endeared bosom, humbly thus
Forgets his honour, and from your high hand,
Invokes revenge for wounding Ferdinand.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Still he surmounts me in an honoured love,
Rise, friend; or if thou strivest to have the world,
In me, as in a glass, see a false friend.
Behold, I kneel, and here proclaim to all,
My friendship's broke, but thine substantial.

sp.speaker: Na.
sp.l: Model of virtue, honoured Pembroke's Earl,
Rise in as dear regard as Ferdinand.
O, had I Bellamira once in hold,
Age would turn youth, and I should never be old.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Had I my Katharina once again,
Our joy were then stretched to the highest strain:
But she was ravished, and then murdered.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Bear not that hard opinion: Rodorick's tongue
Slandered that prince, and did his virtue wrong.

sp.speaker: Pem.
sp.l: Lewis of France, hear what an English Earl
Speaks in the front and view of all thy host:
If ever Ferdinand stained Katherine's honour,
I was a party: yet in all your camp,
Who dares step forth and call me ravisher?
No, France, know Pembroke is an Englishman,
Highly derived, yet higher in my thoughts;
And for to register mine acts in brass,
Which all-devouring time shall never raze out,
Have I through all the courts of Christendom,
In knightly trial proved my virtue sound,
Raised England's fame aloft; and shall I now,
In her next continent, her neighbour realm.
France, on whose bosom I may stand and see
That blessed soil, that bred and fostered me,
Soil all my late got honour, to consent
Unto a royal prince's ravishment?
I'd sooner from a mountain cast myself,
Or from a hungry lion tear his prey,
Then dare to act a deed so infamous:
But words are air: Lewis, behold this face;
This proves our honour clear from all disgrace.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: My Katharine!

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: My dear sister!

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: My fair love!

sp.speaker: Pem.
sp.l: See, princes, love's effect: she flies your hand,
To live embraced with her dear Ferdinand.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: And heaven forbid that we should sunder them.
Navarre, reach me thy hand: grim war is fled,
And peace shall end the same in a nuptial bed.
Son Philip, ratify your sister's choice.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Even with my soul: for ever live you blessed.
O Bellamira, had not cursed Burbon,
For beauty robbed thy cheeks with leprosy:
Hadst thou but stayed with me, as is their state,
So had been mine, happy and fortunate.

div.stage: Enter clown attired like a gentleman, Bellamira following with a scarf on her face.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: By your leave, sweet bloods: may a gentleman or so, deceive two or three ounces of words in this assembly?

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.p: You may.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Is there not a young King's son amongst you, who treading the steps of his father, is called Philip?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: I am the man thou seekst.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Then the old saying is verified, he that seeks, shall find. Here is a poor kinswoman of mine would desire some private conference with you, or so.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: With me? whom see I? Bellamira!

sp.speaker: Nau.
sp.l: Daughter!

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Do not deride my woes, speak, speak, I pray.

sp.speaker: Pem.
sp.l: Look not so strange, it is thy lovely love,
thus managed, to approve thy constancy.
Embrace her then: and now Navarre and France,
Here end your strife, and let all hatred fall,
And turn this war to Hymen's festival.

sp.speaker: Nau.
sp.l: This Pembroke's counsel we subscribe unto.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: The like doth France: lovers embrace your loves;
And captains, join your bands, mix power with power,
And let those swords, which late were drawn for death,
Sleep in their sheaths. You, worthy Pembroke,
And all your followers, shall receive our favours,
In plenteous largesse: so, set on to court;
Sound drums and trumpets, deaf the air with cries,
And fill each subject's heart with joys increase,
T'applaud our children's love, and this day's peace.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
